text:
This recipe is fantastic - Never make the Karo Syrup recipe again!  I'm disappointed I didn't have this recipe years ago - it is infinately better than the standard corn syrup recipes, and just as easy.  This recipe tastes more like real pie, instead of like candy.  I also recommend using Mrs Smith's deep dish pie crusts instead of the cheaper lard crusts - it bakes better.  Warm the eggs to room temp before making this recipe - will keep the butter from clumping when you add it to the eggs.

text:
My husband and I run a restaurant and we have used this recipe as one of our desserts.  Our customers always rave about it!  The only thing I do differently is that I reduce the temperature of the oven to about 300 and cook it longer, until it starts to crack on the top.  This way it does not get over browned on the top.  A great recipe!

text:
I tried this recipe twice and got a different result each time. Third time is a charm, right? Unfortunately not. Then I brightened up and decided to read reviews. What I was experiencing was written in every negative review I read.

First let me say that the taste of this pie is absolutely phenomenal!! A little sweet, yes, but great! My issue is with the unappetizing souffle-type top and that the filling really doesn't fill my dish, leaving a big gap between crust and filling, making my crust crumble down into the pie. Not pretty. But notice the serving calculator underneath the recipe? Problem solved. 

Everything else I would follow to a "T" except that I would decrease baking temp to 300 degrees and bake 45 mins.Anyone that knows anything about pretty pies knows that if your crust goes, then forget the pie! This temp has burnt my crust each time, even with my crust sleeve on it--SO frustrating. The other change would be to add another 1/2 cup of pecans AFTER the filling is in the shell. That way you'll still have a nice appearance on the top of the pie. 

One thing that some mentioned was that this pie is dry-----this pie----let me repeat----this pie IS NOT DRY! You get somewhat of a crust on top from the souffle-style filling, but underneath that is rich ooey-gooey goodness!!

text:
I was hesitant to try this recipe when I noticed corn syrup was not listed as an ingredient.  Well, I tried the recipe & the pie was awesome! I mixed sugars & butter well with a portable mixer while butter was hot, to eliminate a grainy texture, added 1/2 c choco. chips, 1/4 c additional 
pecans, then baked for 10 mins @ 400, reduce oven temp to 350 baked for 20 additional mins, reduce oven temp to 325 & bake an additional 10 mins until middle of pie settled. I reduced baking temp to eliminate burning the pie before it was done.  However it was worth the adjustments. It was magnificent! Thanks for sharing!

text:
My husband and I enjoyed this version of pecan pie very much.  I lowered the calorie count even more by using 3/4C brown sugar and 1/2 C Splenda, and I used heart healthy margarine instead of butter.  Best eaten warm.  I am a traditional cook in pecan country and was skeptical until I tried it.  I had given up making pecan pies because of the high calorie and saturated fat counts so I am thrilled to have this recipe.

text:
Great recipe! To summarize the advice I took from the previous reviews: - Heat butter just until melted, too hot could cook the egg - Preheat oven to 350 deg. F, and place pie in oven for 10 minutes. - Remove pie from oven and turn temp. down to 300 deg. F, place halved pecans on top for a more appealing pie. - Bake at 300 for 50 minutes longer or until the pie is puffed and set. Pie received strong approval from a Charleston, SC, native, pecan pie connoisseur.

text:
Very good, but still too sweet. This is plenty sweet with just 1 cup of brown sugar, cut out the white completely. I used 2 tablespoons flour instead of one to have a thicker consistency since there is no corn syrup. This also helps the pie slice better.  I added 1.5 cups of chopped pecans plus a layer of whole pecans on top. I followed tip of baking 10 min/400 degrees, 20 min/350 degrees, 20 min./325 degrees (tip worked great). Pie is done when it slightly cracks on top.  I used 'Basic Flaky Pie Crust' froom this site for the crust.  I will definitely make again but with less sugar.

text:
I love this recipe.  I have been making it for a couple years now.  Instead of making it as one whole pie, I usually use the refrig pie crust and roll it out thinner, use a biscuit cutter and cut a bunch of small crust out of it, put the crust in a cup cake pan, and fill those about 1/2 full with the filling.  Bake at 350 for 25 min.  It makes about 2 dozen little pecan pies and that way you have way more to go around.

text:
Delicious! I was so happy that my first ever pecan pie came out great thanks to this recipe. As another reviewer said, I got a little confused about the oven temp (pre-heated it to 350 but it says to cook it at 400 for the first ten minutes), so I don't know if my oven temp was perfect, but the pie still came out great! Just preheat your oven to 400 and then turn it down to 350 after 10 minutes of baking. I highly recommend this recipe.

text:
This is definitely a winner and so easy to make. I've made this exactly as written as well as my own version with couple adjustments. I highly recommend considering suggested tips: toast the CHOPPED pecans for about 12-15 minutes in a 350 preheated oven. It completely changes the pie from delicious to orgasmic. It enhances the flavor of the pecans and adds a better texture. Leave the top pecans as is though because it will toast automatically when baking. Use a 9 inch deep dish crust instead and bake for 15 minutes at 300 and then 300 for 50 minutes  It's only a tad bit more effort, but definitely goes a long way. Love this recipe!

None
text:
I've tried this 3 times now, and this is what I've discovered...  
A. It tastes awesome no matter what you do! 
B. The more you whip the eggs, the less it looks like traditional pecan pie. 
C. I like the texture better when I added an extra 1/2 cup of pecans (1 1/2 total). 
D. I like it best without the white sugar... I just left it out and didn't miss it at all!
E. Definitely take it out before you think it's done...  it continues to cook, and the one I thought I cooked perfectly came out very dry. 
F. Definitely turned out best for me when cooking at 350 for 10 minutes then 300 for 40 minutes.
G. A little Amaretto in the whipped cream added even more to the DELICIOUS flavor of the pie!! (-:

Oh, and to answer someone's question about the crust, don't cook it first.

(-:

text:
This pie was delicious and very easy to make (the hardest part was waiting to eat it). I love that it's not made with corn syrup because it seems more natural and I generally have brown sugar on hand. One important note is that the pie has to chill for a long time to firm up. Two hours later it was still pretty liquid, it wasn't until it sat overnight that it was the proper consistency. This was my first pecan pie so I don't know if that's common sense to everyone else, but I was surprised, especially since no one mentioned it. I thought I'd ruined the pie until I googled it and realized it needed more time.

text:
First, let me tell you about my husband.  He does not like change.  When he likes a recipe, he loves it and only wants THAT particular recipe.  So, when he asked for a pecan pie and I told him I was trying a new recipe without the Karo he was shocked-  "pecan pie made without Karo?  You know I love your pecan pie."   When it came out of the oven, we both looked at the pie.  That did not look like pecan pie, there wasn't the traditional pecan topping.  He tried it and surprise, surprise, he loved it!  In fact, he said that he liked it BETTER than the Karo recipe!   We used, please don't mock me, a refrigerated pie crust (I know, I know) and baked the entire pie at 350 for 45 minutes.  The crust was a bit darker than I would have liked, but it was not burnt (just a nice George Hammilton brown).   The next time we make this recipe, I'll be making the following changes:  1- I'll flour the top and bottom of the pie crust, prior to putting it into the pie pan (this will help the bottom of the crust from getting soggy (our first attempt stuck to the pan).  2- I'll add powdered sugar after it cools (to make the top look pretty)  3- I'll bake at 350 for 10 minutes, then 300 for another 40-50 minutes- or until the outside is set and the middle slightly jiggles.  4- allow to set OVERNIGHT.   Great recipe!  I still have two bottles of Karo syrup, does anyone want them?

text:
I don't like pecan pie at all because of the extreme sweetness of the store bought variety (hurts my teeth!), and my husband loves it.  I tried this recipe on a whim one night (exactly as written), and it is SO wonderful, so tasty, so perfectly the right texture and sweetness, that I am now in love with pecan pie!  I've made this recipe 3 times with no changes, and it comes out amazing.  The omission of corn syrup must help the sweetness level become normal, because the flavor is delicious.  Please try the recipe; it's even extremely simply to make/throw together while working on a weeknight dinner after a full working day (and that's no easy feat).  You will thank your lucky stars.

text:
All of those positive reviews and the overall rating made me think this would be a good pie. 
All I can figure is that those people who actually rated this recipe high either don't know what a traditional pecan pie should taste like or they're just so opposed to the Karo recipe that the think this is the ONLY and/or BEST option.
To each their own.  
If you decide you're going to make this recipe, add the decorative pecans before you bake the pie.
I
IMPROVEMENTS MADE:  Eliminate white sugar, reduce brown sugar by 1/4 cup and add 1/4 cup pure maple syrup.  Increase pecans by 1/2 cup, crushing the additional pecans.
Also used Almond milk since that's what I had on hand.  Didn't think it would alter the taste or baking since it was such a small amount.
Personal enhancements:  First pie - 2 Tbs Jim Beam Bakers Small Batch Kentucky Bourbon 107 proof.  Second pie - 3 Tbs of same Bourbon.  That pie is MINE.  :-D
Changed oven temp to 350 degrees for first 10 minutes and reduced temperature to 300 degrees for 50 additional minutes.  
Pies came out looking beautiful.  Crust nicely golden and top looks perfect.  Could have baked them 10-15 minutes less and they probably would have been better.
I actually like the consistency of the Karo syrup type of pecan pies -it's just what I'm used to.  This pie was just more like a brown sugar (cake like?) consistency.  The picture provided by Redponygirl will give you a fair idea what the texture inside is like.

text:
This was almost the answer to my diebetic dreams! I made this with Splenda products and it was satisfying and rich. Be sure, however that you are aware that it still contains sugar if using the Splenda blends. You should not rush this pie. Make it so it has enough time to completely cool. I started mine to bake at 350 then backed off to 300 after 10 minutes. Although my oven has a convection setting, I did not use it for this recipe; that would make a difference. I will most certainly make this pie again. My husband and dinner guest enjoyed it. It was fast and easy to make. The tip about making sure the eggs aren't cooked by the melted butter is important.

I was never a fan of pecan pie until I tried this recipe. I love that it doesn't have the sticky gummy consistency of most pecan pies. After the pie has cooled a bit I melt about 20 caramels with 3 tablespoons heavy cream. I add 1/4 cup chopped pecans and spread the mixture over the top of the whole pie. It is awesome.

This is the most simple dessert to make ever.... And sooooo good... Baked it at 350 for 10 minutes, then 300 degrees for an hour.... Delicious... Lower temp for a bit longer time, is better....
To make it look more appealing... After 20 minutes taking it out the oven.... I made a chocolate glaze... Very simple... Melted 3 tbsp butter,  1/2 cup chocolate chips, added 1 tsp vanilla... brushed it on top of pecan pie, added more pecans, and wow... It looks like a pie from a 5 star restaurant... Just added whip cream when I served... And my bf was like... This is simply amazing... And I know I did a great job, if he tells me that he will bring it to work the next day.... text:
Really a nummy pie !  My only recommendations/changes:  When I put the filling into the crust, it only filled it half way.  So I mixed up another 1/2 c brown sugar, 4 tbs white sugar, 1 egg, 1/2 tbs flour, 1/2 tbs milk, 1 tsp vanilla and 1/2 more pecans.  It filled the 'shell' perfectly and looked amazing. I followed the other suggestions of lowering the heat: 10 minutes at 350, then 40 minutes at 300...just til small cracks appeared in the surface.  My family really LOVED this Pecan Pie !!

text:
Delicious and sooo easy!  I loved that it didn't have the traditional super syrupy texture.  I did think it was still a tad too sweet but definitely a keeper.
Adjustments:
I lightly roasted the pecans prior to chopping them.  Chopped them large and added 1 1/2 cups instead of just 1.
Left out the white sugar altogether and will probably still cut the brown sugar in subsequent pies.  
Baked it at 400 for 10 minutes then 45 at 300 rather than 350, turned out great.  I love the contrast of the nice crunchy top and chewy bottom layer.

text:
Delicious pecan pie that will change your idea of what "GREAT" pecan pie should be. No more yucky corn syrup pie ever again. This is sooo much better. Prebaked my pie shell for 7-8 minutes before filling and added about 1/2 cup more pecan halves to the top of the pie before baking. So EZ. Serve warm with vanilla ice cream. Thanks for the wonderful recipe. FYI - If you don't have time to make your own pie crust ... I've found that the Marie Callender's frozen pie shells are very good and bake up nice and flaky. Altho I usually go to the trouble of rerolling them and using my own glass pan ... no soggy bottom and company thinks it is homemade! My secret!

Very good recipe...although if I were to rate it on the day I baked it, I would give it 3 stars.  It just seemed overly sweet to me, but the next day, it was definitely 5 stars.  I guess the flavor needed time to mellow out a bit.  So, prepare this pie the day before you intend to slice into it...you will not be sorry!  Another thing I did was follow the directions for oven temp and time, but I found that the filling was perhaps a tad too dry.  I will follow other reviewers' suggestion and bake for 10 minutes at 350 and then 40-55 minutes at 300.

This recipe is great I have made it a few times and I am a real pecan lover. The first time I made it I added double the pecans....don't do this or it turns out really dry. The second time I chose not to chop the pecans and kept them whole laid on top of the pie and it was exactly what I was looking for. This recipe is nice because you don't have that sickeningly sweet taste left over nor do you feel like your shaking for the sugars. I do recommend making it a day ahead of time which give it a day to or evening to set up better.

country:

text:
I am surprised by all of the gleamingly positive reviews of this recipe. I am a southern gal born and bred in the middle of a pecan orchard and this is not a traditional pecan pie.  The filling bakes too dry and firm--it isn't soft and runny like a classic pecan pie.  And I did not overbake the pie.  The top of the pie is foamy and crunchy.  While this may be fine if you want a pie or tart made with pecans, don't expect it to satisfy your cravings for the pecan pie like your grandmother made.  Look at the photos posted of this recipe and you will see that most of them look dry in the middle.  I will definitely return to the recipe that uses corn syrup for the filling.

text:
This was delish! I made this for Thanksgiving dinner.  I love the traditional flavor of pecan pie, but not too much of the thick ooey-gooey center.  This pie was perfect for me! I did follow the other suggestions to cook at 350 for 15 mins then 300 for 50-55mins.  I also added the sugars to the butter while it was hot to prevent a grainy texture. I did alter the recipe a bit due to ingredients I had on hand: I used dark brown sugar, buttermilk and a regular pilsbury ready-made crust.  I added an extra tbs of flour and a total of 1.5cups pecans in the batter.  I also sprinkled 1/2 cup of chopped pecans on top for a more traditional look(definitely toast the pecans). I refrigerated the pie before serving also.  This is a keeper! Thanks Elaine!

I only decided to try it because it had such good ratings. I will stick to the "real" stuff next time.....yes,the sinful corn syrup. ^_^ ~Jess

my first attempt to make pecan pie and it turned out deadly DELICIOUS!! OMG just discovered my new addiction (this aint good for my diet =P) the recipe is easy and fast the only thing i changed was the baking temp and time. after reading so many reviews i came to this time which is 350/15 min then 300/40 min and it came out AMAAAAZING. the pecan aroma filled the kitchen everybody was wondering what baking ^_^. ill always make this pie its a keeper.

Update (21/5/2015): I discovered that when not overmixing the egg (decrease the amount of air into the egg) i dont have a pie with irregular surface (i used to have bumbs and balloons) so when i mix the eggs i dont overmix it.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been searching for a pecan pie recipe that does not use corn syrup. This is because i never buy/use it and do not want to waste money buying a full bottle just for a recipe.

I tried this recipe tonight and am very happy with the results. I LOVE pecan pie. I have tried making one years ago and failed (undercooked on bottom and burned on top) causing me not to try again. Until today that is.

I followed the recipe except i totally forgot to add the flour. Pie still came out great so i don't know how it would be if i did add the flour. The other small changes i made (after reading the many reviews) was i toasted my pecans first and i used a little less then the 1/4 cup white sugar (like half of that). I added an extra 1/2 cup pecans on top (as i do love pecans). Baked it in a Pillsbury pie crust using a 9" tart pan (did not have a pie pan). I did 350 for 15 minutes then lowered to 300 for 35 minutes. I put 50 minutes but it started to crack at 35 minutes so i turned it off.

Had a slice warm. It was moist and yummy. Will try more tomorrow to see how well it taste overnight.

Overall, i will definitely make this again and again :)

text:
I am not a fan of pecan pie - waayyyy too sweet for me. But my daughter requested a pecan pie and I chose this recipe to make. I wasn't even going to try a piece myself but she insisted and, OMGosh! Fabulous!! I am now a pecan pie lover. Who knew pecan pie could be this delicious and not cloyingly, disgustingly sweet? After reading many of the reviews I did as many of you did and reduced the temperature to 300 degrees for the last 40 minutes and eliminated the white sugar. I also toasted the pecans for the filling for a few minutes in the oven and added 1 cup halved pecans to the top when I reduced the oven temp. I cannot thank you enough for this recipe. It is a favorite at our house now and is devoured almost as fast as I can make it!

This was to be the first Pecan Pie I ever made.  And it was for my new mother and father in-law, who love Pecan Pie.  I did a lot of research and couldn't decide whether to make the Karo version or this version.  So I made both.  Both baked up perfectly but one tasted much better than the other. Don't hesitate to try it.  It is still a Pecan Pie through and through.  Everyone loved it of course.

This was a good pie, BUT let me clarify...this is not what I would call your "traditional" pecan pie.  For those of us, who DO love the traditional pecan pie w/ that gel-ish center that you only get with the corn syrup, this is more like a pecan tassie.  With ALL that said, I want to say again, that this is a very good tasting pie.  I used the Basic Flaky Pie Crust recipe from this site.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
WOW. Made this for our Thanksgiving Dinner and it was first to go. I was a bit worried at the way it looked as it didn't look like your typical Pecan Pie. We used a Deep Dish Pie Pan and made our own crust. So when we filled the pie it didn't fill it up. So we quickly made another 1/2 batch to fill the rest up. We also placed Whole pecans on top to dress up the top of the pie. It does rise a bit so be careful. We baked it for 10 minutes at 350 and then lowered the temp to 300 and baked for another 60-65 (remember we had a deep dish so it will take less if you are doing a regular sized pie). All we can say is AWESOME. Everyone wanted the recipe. The insides of ours was a bit runny at first. We cut a piece out to test it and it tasted awesome, but it was a tad runny. Once it set there while we ate dinner it set up for some reason. All I can say is TRY THIS RECIPE. You won't be sorry.

text:
I had been hesitant about trying this pie, I tend to lean toward tried and true recipes.  However, a friend was looking for a less syrupy pecan pie so I bit the bullet and gave this one a shot.  I am so glad I did.  I am replacing my old recipe with this one.  It's gooey and sweet, but not too sweet.  I added a half cup more pecans and the result was perfection.  People actually moaned as they bit into this one.  

I did allow my eggs to come to room temperature before beating.  I baked at 350 for 40 minutes until I had a golden brown crust on top.  You certainly won't be sorry that you tried this.  I sure wasn't.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
I loved the taste of this pie. I did not give it 5 starts because of the thin unattractive layer it leaves on the top.  Really would look unappetizing without some pecan halves thrown on the top part-way through baking.  But, the taste is fabulous and my 2 pecan-pie loving friends really enjoyed it.

For baking, I pre-heated the oven to 400 degrees and baked for 10 minutes.  Then, I left the pie in the oven and turned the heat down to 350 degrees.  It was done in another 25 minutes (so 35 mins total baking time) and I probably could have cooked it a little less and it would have been o.k.  I think for Christmas, I will put a "spiced pecan" on each slice.  I added the pecans to the top about 10 minutes before it was done. 

What this pie lacks in presentation, it makes up for in flavor and consistancy.

I live out of the USA and really miss pecan pie.  Unfortunately I rarely find pecans at the market and never have seen corn syrup.  Well my mom sent me some nice pecans and I had to try for pecan pie.  I used this recipe but without any white sugar but instead substituted a half cup of real maple syrup. I shared it with a friend all living here from Texas and she and her husband couldn't believe how good it was!

text:
To me, the regular pecan pie recipes are too sticky and sweet. This recipe produces an excellent pie, but I took the advice from so many, and made the following changes. 1.  12 minutes at 375, 45 minutes at 300. 2. 1 cup of pecans in the mix, 1/2 more placed on top neatly. 3. I put a tablespoon of crown in the mix. Can't taste it, but adds balance. Mine came out delicious.  One note, the filling isn't as thick as some recipes, but it tasted great.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
WOW! I just used this recipe to make my first ever pecan pie and it was awesome! No gummy, stick to your teeth goo in this pie. Hubby and I were looking for a pecan pie recipe that would not snatch the dentures out of someone's mouth and this is the one. We have had to make do with tiny slivers of store bought and family made pies due to the extreme stickiness of the filling. This was great, we both had huge slices...so yummy! I baked it with the additional 1/2 cup of pecans, brushed the unbaked crust with egg whites to keep it from getting soggy and used the 350 degrees for 10 minutes followed by 300 degrees for 55 minutes and the crust was perfectly done...flaky and tender. I will make this several times this holiday season!

The first time I made this I followed the recipe as is. It came out too brown on top and a little runny but the flavor was good. text:
This was AMAZing!! Sweet (but not sickeningly so) and nutty and yummy. Everyone at our Thanksgiving raved about it. I think I'll take the advice of another reviewer and add chocolate chips next time too. The pie set up fine, just bake it until the crust cracks a bit. I also reduced my oven temp to 350 for 15 mins, then 300 for 50-55. This left even the store bought crust in amazing, golden brown shape.

It was very good - won second place in a pie contest.  All I did different was add about 1/2 tsp of cinnamon and some fresh grated nutmeg.  I definitely had to protect the crust after the first 15 or 20 minutes because it was already getting dark.  I took it out at 45 minutes total cooking time and the center ended up not setting completely - it had the consistency of caramel.  Next time I'll probably cook it 10 more minutes.

This Pecan Pie is always a WIN/WIN for me. Everyone always loves it, and it is super easy to make. text:
This is THE BEST pecan pie I have ever had.  Much better than the ones with corn syrup, none of the gelatin like texture or the syrupy sweetness with this pie.  This one is heavenly.  I did bake the crust first, which was a mistake, so don't pre-cook the crust!  Thank you Elaine!! A note to the reviewer who said the texture was grainy, I found if you let it sit a day or so after baking, the texture changes and you have a very smooth filling.

text:
I had never made a pecan pie before, but knew I didn't want to use Karo syrup. This recipe is delicious! I read through the other comments ahead of time and made a few tweaks though: (1) I lightly toasted the pecans in the toaster oven before adding them into the mixture (2) I added cinnamon (3) instead of making one full-sized pie, I used a large muffin tin to make 6 mini pies. They are the perfect size for sharing and reheat in the toaster oven quite nicely!

text:
Except for increasing the measurement for pecans to 1-1/2 cups, I followed this recipe exactly.  I made 3 pies for Thanksgiving along with Pumpkin, Apple, and several other desserts (had a big group).  The Pecan was the hit of the night.  Everyone loved it and many told me it was the best Pecan Pie they ever tasted.  It was my first time making Pecan Pie so I felt so great.  It wasn't overly sweet, and it set up very well.  I did lose track of time and accidentally cooked it a few minutes longer than I was supposed to but the result was still amazing.  This is a keeper and I no longer need to look for any other.  I was so happy to see it didn't need corn syrup since it's something I normally don't keep on hand.  One thing I did do was mix the sugars in with the warm butter to avoid any grainy texture.  Worked like a charm.  Thanks for the fab recipe!

text:
My boyfriend made this pie for Thanksgiving & Christmas.The first time he made it, the pie did not form that disgusting crust on the top. I totally enjoyed the first pie. Every pie since has formed that crust and I SERIOUSLY dislike that crust. My boyfriend says I "eat with my eyes" & that is very much true. He also tried "perfecting it" by added a more gooey filling, which I don't like either. So I made it myself today & it's delicious. I can't tell you how many of these reviews I read yesterday in prerpartion of making this pie. I am so thankful to you ladies for all the good suggestions. I only used light brown sugar (apprx. 1.5 c), I took many suggestions and added .5 c of pecans, I used 2 tbsp of milk and I did not totally melt the better. I think the key to avoiding that disgusting crust from foaming at the top was possibly slightly beating the eggs (just a little bit of bubble) & slow baking.I will use less butter the next time I make it, but this pie turned out wonderful!. So sweet and NOT dry at all as many negative reviewers stated. Also, I must note- I USED to like the traditional super sweet and gooey pecan pie. This pie is so much better and more classy in my opinion. It has the perfect amount of crunch vs. sweet ratio. I highly recommend anyone considering this pie to first DO YOUR RESEARCH and then try it. I doubt you will regret it! T O! I almost forgot -- I uploaded a photo of my pie!

None
text:
I altered this recipe a little. Instead of using sugar. I only used 1/4 cup of agave nectar. Agave nectar has a natural sweet taste, so a little agave will work, and it will also help to cut down on sugar and calories. I also added 1/2 cup of ground quinoa seeds to make a healthier pie. It was delicious. My family loved it.  I also made my own crust. There is a recipe on this site for a No Roll Crust pie. I altered that recipe and I used 1 1/2 cups of whole wheat flour, 1 cup of grated unsweetened coconut, 1 cup of ground quinoa seeds grond into a flour , 1/2 of whole flaxseeds. Do not grind them for this recipe it will not work well. 1 tablespoon of agave nectar, 1tbs of cinnamon powder,  1/2 tsp. sea salt, and 1tbs of vanilla essence, and 1/2 cup of extra virgin coconut oil.  I got two (2) pie shells from that recipe and I pressed them down into the 9in pie dishes. I took a fork, and punched holes through the pie shells, and I baked them for 45mins. at 250 degrees because coconut oil burns at high temperature, and also to preserve the nutrients in the pie crusts. It was delicious!!! You can still enjoy desserts, just make them a little healthier!!!! Enjoy!!!

text:
This was so easy and so good!!!  I just beat the eggs until there were bubbles on top (not long at all).  Cooked 10 minutes on 400, then switched to 350 and after about 5 minutes decided to switch to 325 for about 40 more minutes.  Checked on it a couple of minutes before the timer was done and the pies(made a double batch) were cracked on top.  Couldn't wait more than a few minutes before temptation took over.  Made one pie per the recipe and the second I added some Heath toffee bits with chocolate.  Both tasted great!!!  The whole family loved them.  Mine did not have a gritty texture as mentioned in some other reviews.  Best pecan pies I have ever had!!!

text:
Delicious!  Nice alternative to the traditional Karo syrup pecan pie.  I noticed that a member named "Kym" (a beginner cook) asked a question along with the picture that she posted.  To answer her -- Kym, I believe you simply cooked the pie too long. That can cause the top to become very poofy.  Next time, try removing it while the center is still slightly jiggly.  It will set up as it cools.  Also, your oven may run a little hot, causing the poof to occur before the cook time is finished.  Might want to invest in an oven thermometer (very inexpensive and can be found in any kitchen store, Walmart and grocery stores).  You can set or hang the thermometer in the oven to test the actual temp.  If it's off, adjust recipes temps accordingly.  The correct temp makes all the difference in baking cakes, pies, cheesecakes, etc.  Hope that helps you have better luck next time!  Have fun with your learning adventure and don't be afraid to keep trying -- you'll have it down pat in no time! :)

I'm about to skew the ratings, but I don't think you'll mind - here's why! I wanted to taste the difference b/t a pecan pie, bite for bite, made with and without corn syrup.  So, I made two and this recipe hardly compared in taste and color.  While it might have passed for pecan pie on its own, I agree with the oter reviewers who say this isn't 'traditional' in taste.  It has a thicker, more flour-y taste/consistency and desparately needs more [toasted]pecans. The winning recipe was from Baking Illustrated and was complete with 2 cups of TOASTED and CHOPPED pecans.

text:
WOW!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
My kids and husband loved it. I baked three that Monday before Thanksgiving and planned on freezing them until Thursday morning. Well, all gone before Tuesday and not even a crumb left in the pie tins. I had to bake three more. ******** I love pecans so I put 1 1/4 cup of pecans in each pie. I started the recipe with room temp. eggs and I DID NOT super pack the brown sugar (I just made sure it was a full cup by LIGHLY packing) and baked the pies at 350 for 15 mins. Then 300 for 55 mins. Now we can have pecan pie more often, since the ingredents are a staple in our house. A very wholesome but yet delicate pie and definitely a must try.

My aunt & uncle, who live in Indonesia was complaining that they don't sell corn syrup there so they wouldn't be able to have pecan pie for Thanksgiving. Thank you so much for this recipe! It's definitely a keeper!!!!

text:
LOVELY! 2nd pecan pie I've ever made, 2nd recipe. The 1st one had the Karo syrup. While I did like the karo syrup encrusted topping of pecans that that recipe made, this recipe is a much fuller, all around pie. I'm trying to figure out how to incorporate the 2. This pie was very easy to make (I had some leftover pie crust pre-made - Ruth's Grandma's Pie Crust), took me no time to mix up the ingredients. I made a cute flower design of halved pecans on top of the pie and pressed them in half way. I also added about 1/2 tsp more vanilla to the mix and a pinch of salt per reviewers' suggestions. Beautiful! I will make this recipe over and over again!

text:
Pretty good pie. A couple tips I've learned making this pie is to poke a few holes in the bottom of the pie crust with a fork otherwise in my experience the pie dough won't cook all the way through in the middle. If you have a propane stove as I do you want to turn it down to 325 instead of 350 and cook for 35-40 minutes.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have successfully made one (precisely one) karo style pecan pie.  Because it is my boyfriend's favorite dessert, I have attempted (unsuccessfully) to recreate that first miracle of pecan deliciousness many, many times.  To my utter dismay, I could never get them to set.  I had thus given up the battle of the pecan pie, until I recently ran across this recipe...oh sweet mercy.

I followed the mixture of this recipe exactly and it fit perfectly into a frozen deep dish pie crust (though I almost changed the amounts based on another review that said it wasn't enough).  I did, however, follow other people's suggestions and baked it longer and at a lower temperature than the original recipe stated.  300 degrees F for 50-55 minutes worked perfectly to set the ingredients.

The difference, in my "culinarily-challenged" opinion, between the karo and the brown sugar recipe is that this one is more caramel-y in texture (maybe not quite as over-poweringly sweet) whereas the karo version is more syrupy in texture and definitely cavity cringe worthy.

text:
We recently moved to a lovely 1830's farmhouse in SC. The property has over 20 pecan trees. I have never made a pecan pie before because I really did not want to bother. But pecans are falling out of the sky now :-) so I thought it was time. I never use corn syrup so it is not an option in our house. This recipe was spot on! The only two things I did differently was leave a mixture of whole and chopped pecans. And I toasted my pecans for about 5-7 minutes on 350 degrees. Second change came from another reviewer and they suggested to brown the butter and then let it cool before adding it. It got rave reviews and it deserved them. I used a recipe for an awesome butter pastry crust and it was delicious!

I had never made pecan pie.  I used the tips from another user and added 1/4 choc chips.  I had warmed the sugars & butter on top of the stove to prevent the mixture being grainy.  I added a bit of the hot mixture to the eggs to tempure it.  The baking time was 10 min at 400, 20 min at 350 and 10 min at 325.  WOW, it turned out perfect and wasn't too sweet, I had cut down the sugar a bit.  I thought when it came out with a crispy, cracked crust it hadn't turned out....wrong!!  Served with whipped cream was yummy!!  Next time, I would serve with a scoop of ice cream and top with whip cream!!

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2012-12-09T06:35:12.233
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
4878767
Display Name:
Cook Tech
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
6
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used 6 oz pecan pieces (should add pecan halves on top for appearance), added 3 oz of chocolate chips (about 3/4 cup), and left out the white sugar. Left eggs out for up to 1 hr. to allow the egg to mix better. Melted the butter in microwave using 15 sec @ full power, 15 sec @ 80%, 15 sec @ 60%, 15 sec @ 40%, and 15 sec @ 20%. Then first mixed the melted butter with the brown sugar and flour with a wire whisk, to help melt the sugar, and achieve smooth consistency. Then added milk and vanilla to the eggs, and beat the mixture together with a fork. Then added the egg mixture to the sugar and butter mixture, first mixing them together with a plastic spoon, and then with a wire whisk. Then added 1/2 the pecans, mixed together with a plastic spoon, then added the other 1/2, mixed together, and then added the chocolate chips and mixed together. Result was a very evenly mixed pie filling. Poured into the Mrs. Smith pie crusts, and baked for 10 mins @ 400, reduced the oven temp to 350 and baked for 20 additional mins, and then reduced the oven temp to 325 and baked an additional 10 mins until the middle of pie settled. I used this tip from another reviewer to reduce the baking temp to eliminate burning the pie before it was done. PS This was the second attempt. The first attempt was a comical adventure which turned out well anyway. I measured the dry ingredients, put them in a plastic bag, with a small bottle of vanilla, and packed them in my suitcase with a graham cracker crust.

text:
A pecan pie made without Karo syrup intrigued me. So I thought I'd make this one since I always have brown & white sugars, but I have to buy Karo syrup especially to make a pecan pie.  Also, I try to make recipes as written the first time trying, but I didn't have milk, so I used half & half. Other than that I used the exact ingredients. I baked at 400 degress for 10 mins & then 350 degrees for 35 mins.  Was really good, but a little dry. So I made again exactly as I did the first time and just baked 40 mins at 350 degrees, and my son declared it the best pecan pie he's eaten.  He ate the whole pie except 2 pieces.  The taste is phenomenal. This is the way I'll be making pecan pie from now on!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed this recipe exactly with two exceptions: I used a 9 inch pie pan so I had to times the recipe by 1.5 to fill the crust (I used the Pie Crust IV recipe from this site, which is awesome). I also took another reviewer's advice and baked the first 15 minutes at 350 and baked another 50 minutes at 300 and it came out PERFECTLY. I wish I could give this pie 10 stars, it is that good. I don't even like pecan pie usually but I absolutely love this one and I think it's because it doesn't call for corn syrup. It really makes a huge difference, it doesn't come out gelatinous like it does with the syrup. The brown and white sugars caramelize beautifully and I really like the chopped pecans over the whole ones. The presentation is nicer and it's easier to cut and chew and it really gives it a richer flavor and texture. A+++

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Amazing! No more corn syrup! I was really worried about making this recipe. I made four of these pies. I used regular size store bought crust. I wrapped the edges in aluminum foil. 

I made two of the pies with the flour and two without. The two without the flour came out much prettier. The pecans rose to the top all on their own. I had sprinkled some extra on top of all four pies as advised by other reviewers. The pies where I used flour almost hid even the pecans I had sprinkled on top. They were not as attractive. We only tried the pie without the flour as I was a bit worried about those especially, but it was wonderful! I haven't yet tried the pies with the flour but I would recommend omitting the flour all together since the result is a very pretty pie that tastes amazing.

  I cooked the pies at 350 for 15 minutes, and 300 for 50 minutes, until it passed the clean knife test. It looked a teeny bit wobbly right out of the oven but set up great after it had cooled.

 My husband loved it even though he was very skeptical at first, now it is the only version he wants to make from now on!

text:
I followed the recipe as written and my pie never solidified.  The filling had a very thin, runny consistency and ran all over the plates when served.  It was also EXTREMELY sweet (no less so than the pies made with Karo) and formed a top "crust" that had a gritty texture and was not very appealing.  The flavor was nice (very caramel-like) but I could definitely taste the graininess of all the sugar.  I so wanted to like this recipe, but I doubt I will be using it again (at least not without some serious modifications).  :(

This is delicious! I made it this weekend to try out before Thanksgiving day and it was amazing! I used dark brown sugar and added 1/4 cup more chopped pecans but to the bottom of the pie shell (they float up). I also baked for 15 min. at 350, then for 40 minutes at 300...it was perfect! It continues to cook after you take out of oven so don't overbake! Let cool for a few hours so pie will really harden. Delicious! And no corn syrup!

text:
I made this today and it is great. Personally, I think it is better than the ones made with corn syrup. It is good and sweet, but not sickening sweet. Please note in the recipe it does not call for the brown sugar to be packed; this could be overlooked by some. I also followed the advise of others and started out baking at 350 and reduced to 300. Because of the butter amount, you still end up with a crispy crust on the bottom even with the lower temps. This will be my go to recipe from here on out. I've tried many others, but this one is by far the best.

This recipe is top of the line. My husband is from the south, and pecan pie has always been his favorite dessert. He says that this recipe makes the best pie he has ever eaten. I've made this recipe many times, and I've never had a problem. I always follow it exactly, including the baking times and temperatures, except that I usually add more pecans, especially to put pecan halves on the top (before baking) so that it looks special, since this is his "birthday pie." If you're looking for an easy, fool-proof pecan-pie recipe, this is it; it's much, much better than any corn-syrup (or other pecan-pie) recipe, and I've tried quite a few.  Thanks, Elaine!

text:
This recipe is awesome.  Many reviewers commented that it didn't look like pecan pie.  Easy to fix. We like lots of nuts so I mix the cup of chopped pecans with other filling ingredients then place a cup or so of pecan halves decoratively on top just before placing it in the oven. Also I've made this pie several times in my convection oven.  I preheat to 400 degrees then turn down the temp as soon as I put the pie in the oven. Otherwise it gets too dark on top.

text:
Finally a pie that isn't overtly sweet!  I really like this recipe.  It is true, the pie doesn't look like the traditional pecan pie with a nice layer of pecans at top.  But this isn't a traditional recipe!  The fact that it doesn't call for corn syrup is what I hold this recipe to be superior among others.  The flavor is buttery and sweet without being overpowering.  I doubled on the pecans which cut back the sweetness even further and made the pie more dense.  I also followed other reviewer's advise and baked at 350 for 15 mins, then lowered the temperature to 300 for 45 mins.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
This was fabulous. Other reviews said it was crumbly, but I didn't have any problems like that. (If its crumbly it may be overcooked. Pecan pie is done when the whole pie jiggles as one semi solid piece. If the middle jiggles on its own its not set. I found that these pies, and I baked two at a time were done after 10 minutes at 400 as per the recipe plus another 20-30 minutes rather than the 30-40 minutes stated.)  This will be the only recipe of pecan pie I make.

text:
TO DIE FOR!  I just love the fact that there is no corn syrup!  I made a double batch and it filled my deep dish 9 inch glass pie pan perfectly.  I followed the suggestions to cook at 350 for 15 then 300 for 55 - it wrked perfectly!  I also added more nuts on top which may not have been necessary as the nuts sort of float to the top as it bakes.  Make sure when you add the melted butter to the whipped eggs the butter has cooled or you will get scrambled eggs!  I tempered the eggs and it was fine.  I used the recipe for  Ruth's Grandma's Pie Crust  instead of a store bought.  Why go to the trouble to make scratch pie and use a store bought crust?  the recipe is very easy and is my favorite.

This is an excellent recipe! Highly recommend! I've made this twice, following the recipe exactly the first time-5 stars. text:
I'm a big fan of pecan pie but find it too goopy sweet to eat very often.  This recipe IS a good improvement BUT it is not pecan pie.  More like, pecan cake in a pie shell.  It's consistency is also really crumbly so it tastes great with ice cream but it won't hold its shape.  So for those of you thinking about making this -- do so!  It's great!  But don't think that you are making something that others will consider a good pecan pie because it's too different.

text:
This recipe was pretty easy, amounts were good, filled the pie exactly. The problem I had was not the taste but how it looked. I didn't put any pecans on the top before baking, thought I'd add them when the pie firmed up a little. The problem was that putting it in at 400 immediately put a hard crust on the pie so putting pecans on was no longer a possibility. I'm used to seeing pecan pies with a soft top, not a leathery brown hard top. Other than appearances, the pie tastes great. So I might try it again with the suggestions of reviewers to bake it longer at a less hot temperature.

Really good!  Follow the cooking instructions provided in the recipe, not the suggestions to lower the temperature.  The first time I made it, I used a lower temperature and it didn't set.  The second time I followed the recipe (400 then down to 350) and it was perfect.  When I stuck a knife in it, the inside was still runny but it looked done so I took it out.  It set up perfect once it cooled.  Tasted even better after refrigerating.

text:
Eight years later, I'm still making this pie for the Thanksgiving dinner. Still making without a crust. Still love it!!! I usually double the recipe. 

This was my review from 2009. Very yummy!!! I'm hooked! Very tasty.  I used less sugar though and it's still pretty sweet.  I baked it in my Kitchen Aid toaster oven. The temp. should be adjusted for that - about 300 F for 30 -40 min. after 350 for 15 min. Also helps to cover the edges of crust with foil for the first 15 min. of baking.  The second time I made this pie I just made it without the crust - I just love this filling so much. Thank you for the wonderful recipe!

text:
The pie was great,  I made my pie in a 9 inch glass pie dish, yet after making my pie filling, it only filled half of the dish so I had to go back and make another batch just so the pie filled up to the top of my pie crust. This recipe does not fill a 9 inch glass pie dish. Because I doubled the filling, I ended up baking it for about 10 - 15 minutes longer than the recipe said to. Since I had so many issues with the recipe, I was very nervous while the pie was baking, but it still turned out very well. I don’t like that jelly-like consistency that corn syrup pecan pies tend to have, and this pie didn’t have that. It had a nice consistency and a wonderful flavor.

text:
This pie is delicious, but there's a little glitch in the instructions.  It says to preheat oven to 350, but it should be 400, as that should be the temp when the pie first goes in the oven. Mis-info like that can throw a novice bake like me into a panic! Also the ingredient list should say melted butter.  Those fixes are minor, and as I said, this pie is absolutely wonderful. I took the leftovers to work because I was afraid I would eat the whole thing in a day!

text:
This is the best-tasting pecan pie because it is not sticky, guey like corn syrup versions.  It also helps people with corn allergies to enjoy this kind of pie again.  Also, I found that using Land o'Lakes salted butter makes it taste the best.  My co-workers have commented on how wonderful it was, and one said that it was the best he had ever eaten; I treat them every now and then with homemade goodies. My pies also have alot better look than the photo uploaded on the page.  Mine has an smooth like glaze look to it, and evenly browned.  Remember, the pecans have to be chopped; I chop mine small in my KitchenAid Food Processor, small bowl attachment.

Hi Elaine:  Just add my thanks to the rest.  I have been cutting out corn syrup, so have been looking for a recipe without it for a few months.  THIS IS DELICIOUS PIE  That said, I did every modification to reduce calories that I could, and it still tasted lots better than traditional pecan pie. text:
This was a hit at Thanksgiving.  Here is what you need to know:  if you have crazy picky people who are expecting the supersweet gel-like base of a traditional corn syrup pecan pie, find another recipe. If that is not the case, this pie is delicious.  Sugar caramelizes when it cooks, corn syrup does not.  This pie is rich and dense with a deeper, not so sticky sweet flavor.

text:
My dad loves pecan pie so I was excited to make this for him.  He thought it was just "eh".  He likes the consistency of the corn syrup-based pecan pie better, and I'd have to agree.  Maybe we're creatures of habit, but the consistency of this pie was just a little weird for me.  Too soft.  I added more pecans as many of the reviewers suggested, and still felt like I didn't get enough of the pecan flavor.  The corn syrup-based fillings seems to bring out the pecan flavor better for some reason, even though I don't like the idea of using corn syrup.  Not a bad recipe, just not for me.

text:
I was a bit hesitant to try this, as I am a HUGE fan of the corn syrup/sticky version of pecan pie. However, I was pleasantly surprised and found this version quite delicious and addicting! It is not sticky at all, and a bit  "lighter" in texture then the corn syrup version, but still has a dense filling. I used the tip of baking it at 400 degrees for 10 mins then turning the oven down to 300 degrees for the remainder of the time. I used 1 and a half cups of pecans and omitted the white sugar as I added some chocolate chips/chunks, a keeper!

text:
Wow, this pie really was amazing. I changed hardly anything, but I used dark brown sugar and added a tablespoon of corn syrup to help give it a gooey center, which I like. I don't necessarily know if it needed it since I'm not very experienced as a chef, however the end result was exactly what I was looking for: firm with a crust on the outside, soft on the inside but not liquidy or like glue. It was perfect.

The only problem I ran into was that I had to double to recipe to fill a glass pie pan. Perhaps it was a deep-dish but for what I believe was a 9-inch pie pan, I would suggest doubling or at least making 1.5 times the said amounts.

Otherwise an amazing pie that everyone loved, even former pecan-pie-haters!

Fantastic! My first attempt at pecan pie. All the pecans pies I had seen before looked slimy. Not this one. It set up beautifully after cooling I cut a piece and it didn't run all over the pan. text:
This pie was extremely easy to make and turned out delicious. My entire family loved it and requested that I make it again for holiday gatherings. However, the bake time suggested is a little off. I use an electric oven which cooks fast, so I set the temperature to 350 and baked for 40 minutes. It still came out a little burnt around the edges so next time I'll decrease the bake time to 30-35 minutes. But overall a wonderfully easy pecan pie!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So I truly enjoyed this pie. I will be honest and say the soufflé texture on top turned me off. I will never bake with corn syrup and this will be my go-to. Room temp eggs didn't make a difference to me. Simply pour the melted butter in slowly as the mixer goes to distribute the heat without cooking the egg. I too feel that baking lower - 300 - was best. Takes approx 75 min with my oven. And i learned the hard way that its best to let it set over night. Wonderful and can trade the top texture with the corn syrup. Instead of whole pecans on top, i'll wait and add them half way during cooking so they don't sink into the soufflé.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have never made a pecan pie before this recipe (and rarely made many other pies either). My husband is from the south and a lover of pecan pie so I thought I’d try it out. I actually doubled the recipe because some family was visiting. Oh my goodness! It was perfection! So simple and turned out beautifully. I don’t like to change much when trying out a recipe for the first time, but I did modify cooking temp based on reviews. I did 15 minutes at 350 followed by 55 at 300. I was worried because the pecans seemed to float at the top when I poured the mixture in the pie crust, but this didn’t change anything. The pie looked lovely and tasted delicious! My husband likes it with a scoop of vanilla ice cream. Definitely will be making it again soon!

text:
I followed the recipe but tripled it to make two large pies. Also followed the advice given here to cook it slower on 300* and used 30 oz of pecans, so more than the recipe calls for. I placed a layer of pecans directly on the crust, poured the filling over that, then added the rest of the pecans to the top, gently pressing them into the filling so they were not just sitting on top. I prefer my pecans to not be chopped, so kept them mainly halved. I really like the no corn syrup method- mainly why I chose this since I don't usually use corn syrup when baking. Will definitely be making this again!

text:
From reading the other reviews, I made 4 adjustments. First, I doubled the recipe for the 10" pie plate I used. Second, I used 3/4 cup of dark brown sugar, 1/2 cup of Splenda and skipped the white sugar altogether. Third, I topped the pie with 1/2 to 3/4 cup of extra pecan halves.  Fourth, I reduced the temp and increased the time of baking.  I baked the pie for 10 min at 350 and then for 50-55 min at 300.

text:
I was just starting my Christmas eve baking when I realised that I forgot to buy the corn syrup. Not wanting to go back out to the store again in the holiday madness, I found this recipe. I may never use corn syrup again. Lovely velvety texture, and the brown sugar complements the pecans without overpowering with sticky sweetness. If you like sticky sweetness (I'm not a fan) you may find this disappointing from the traditional recipe, but I liked this better than any pecan pie I've made. Marvellous.

text:
When great-grandma died, our family lost more than our matriarch, we lost our famed pie maker. No one else in my family would touch Pecan Pie with a ten foot pole, so I (at the ripe age of 25) naively stepped up. 

I try hard to use nice, basic ingredients when cooking, and  have never enjoyed the gooey Pecan Pies I had been served. 

This is THE Pecan Pie my family craves. Every single year! I'm a magician to some family members who refuse to believe it's a simple pie. But hey, I'll take it! 

I always cover my crust, and after filling the pie, float whole pecan pieces on top of the pie to make decorative patterns. Rave reviews every time!

Be sure to beat the eggs long enough, until foamy. It's kinda important.

text:
This pecan pie is freakin' delicious! I never cared for pecan pie but my bf requested it so I tried my best to make him 1.  I've already made 2 since i discovered this recipe a few days ago. I followed the directions exact. I added halved pecans on top like many of the photos I saw. I used a pie crust recipe I found here on allrecipes.com called "Ruth's Grandma's Pie Crust" which I highly recommend. I followed the advice of other reviewers and baked the pie at 350 for 15 min and then 300 for 45 min. If you make your own crust bake the crust alone, without the pie filling, for 10 min at 350.I liked that I didn't have to buy corn syrup like most of the other recipes. Tip: Pecans are expensive but I found a great deal at Costco; Pecan halves 2lbs for $13.

country:
None
text:
I have to confess - pecan pie was always a "meh" kind of food for me, and I made it because I had old pecans in the pantry and because my mom adores pecan pie. Well, this recipe showed me that my problem was not that I don't like pecan pie that much, but that I've never had a really good one. 

I didn't have corn syrup and wasn't about to go out and buy some (I'm serious when I say that I don't even know what people use it for), so I looked for a recipe without it. This was amazing! So amazing, in fact, that I am actually rating/reviewing a recipe on here for the first time. 

I don't like my sweets too sweet so I mostly cut out the extra white sugar, and enjoyed it so much that I had to restrain myself from eating half the pie in one go. I used Deb Perelman's crust recipe from Smitten Kitchen, which was also great (not least because it yielded enough crust for three separate pies).  

Agreed with the reviewers that the temperature may be a bit high - I followed instructions and it was just a bit overdone, but I'm still giving it 5 stars because the flavour was THAT good. Thanks for making me change my mind about pecan pie!

text:
So unbelievably good! Make sure you really whip everything together real good, and you'll have a nice layer of delicious meringue-like topping after baking.  
This is an absolute favourite in my house; I get requests to make it all the time. 
I always preheat the oven to 350, bake for ten minutes, and turn it down to 300 for a nice long and slow bake. It usually takes about an hour, but you'll know it's done when the top starts to crack.

text:
You don't understand: You NEED to make this pie. My previous go-to recipe was a chocolate pecan pie with an all butter crust.  I didn't think that could be improved on.  Then I made THIS PIE.  My husband, who does not like pecan pie, publicly declared this to be the best dessert he had ever tasted: at thanksgiving - in front of his mother.  I was thrilled....I just had to pretend I didn't hear him.  We can't insult Mama's cooking.  I did add a handful of dark chocolate chips on the bottom: I couldn't help myself.  I added 3/4 cups of chopped pecans to the filling mix instead of one whole cup.  I baked the pie for 15 minutes at 350, and removed the pie and added 3/4 cups pecan halves to the top to make it pretty. I lowered the oven temp to 300 and baked it for 50 minutes, only to be rewarded with PIE PERFECTION.  No strange gelatinous insides, no fused-together pecan mass on top. This was what a real homemade pie should taste like. This will become a holiday tradition for us.

text:
I tried this & it was well received.  After following the recipe I made the following changes:   All brown sugar (gives it a deeper flavor), toasted the chopped nuts & increased to 1 1/3 cups (richer flavor & helps carry sweetness), when turning down the oven I took the pie out and arranged halved pecans decoratively on top of the pie.  Also followed 400 for 10 minutes 325 for 55 minutes.  Everyone's oven varies slightly, read the recipe/reviews & you'll get the idea.  Pie will be set at edges & jiggle in the center.  It will set up as it cools.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made exactly as described, except the baking temperature. Based on the recommendation in various reviews, I started 350F for 15min, then, 300F for 55min. Liked the appearance when came out of oven. I noted when I poured the filling in the pie crust, pecan sank in the bottom part of crust, and I couldn't see much pecan on top, so I gently mixed the filling in the crust by using a fork, so the pecan came back to the surface of the pie.  Not sure how much difference this would have made to the surface appearance of the pie, but there was a nice blend of pecan on the surface of the pie, so I liked it :) The filling was less gooey as compare to the traditional recipe, perhaps due to not adding corn syrup, but again, I liked this way. For me personally, I didn't need an extra 1/2 cup pecan (additional) on top (as many reviewers suggested), and I still tasted plenty of pecan in my piece of pie. I saved an extra 1/2 cup of pecan for my next batch :) Yum, Yum, Yum!!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is really amazing.. I had everything to make it except the pie crust so I made a simple pie crust from scratch..

To make the crust 

mix 1 1/4 flour and 1/4 tsp salt with cold butter cut in cubes (I put the butter in the freezer for like 20 minutes).  After incorporating the butter into the flour add 1/4 cup ice cold water (i just put some water in the freezer till it was almost frozen).  Put aside the dough in the fridge for at least 4 hours.  I also added 1/2 cup of craisins because I didn't have enough pecans.. Even my brother in law who doesn't normally like pecan pie devoured this.. This recipe is awesome especially with these slight adjustments!

Well this recipe doesn't need the chocolate, in fact i think it detracted it's great on its own. But that's not the reason for only 4 stars (cause that wasn't part of the original recipe). So next time I make this yummy pie I will follow exactly as written, but add 1 more cup of chopped pecans (oh and a pinch of salt).

I love pecan pie, but I've never made it before.  Thanks to this recipe, my first try was a huge success!  I didn't pick this recipe because of the "no corn syrup" factor and honestly didn't think that would make much of a difference, but it really dd. The only reason I can't give this five stars is because of the baking time/temperature. Turned out great in the end though :-)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The last time I had pecan pie was 7 years ago before moving to Germany. I thought it was time to make it again. Corn syrup is not readily available in my area, so I decided to make this recipe. I also made my own brown sugar because the one sold here has no moisture in it. This is the best pecan pie I ever had! I couldn't wait for it to cool off, so I had a warm slice. The pie was runny, but delicious nontheless. The filling did not run after it cooled off. It wasn't overly sweet either. The pie tasted the best by the third day (and a little sweeter, too). I'm not ashamed to admit that I ate the whole thing myself (my husband and kids don't like pecan pie) and gained 5 pounds! It was worth every bite. Will definitely make this again for my German MIL (she loves pecans). Thanks for sharing your recipe, Elaine! This is the a real pecan should taste. :-)

I make over 100 pies a year and quite a few are pecan.  THIS IS NOW MY FAVORITE PECAN PIE RECIPE.  I love the consistancy, the flour helping the filling to set.  I only use butter and with the brown sugar, it makes for a delicious filling.  I like to use dark brown sugar and only butter with 1 1/2 to 2 cups of pecans.  I like to chop my pecans because it helps the pie cut better.  Thank you for this recipe.  Where have you been all my life????

text:
Easy to make and comes out every time.   This has become our go-to pecan pie.  I don't think I'll ever make with corn syrup again!  As some others have said, it's plenty sweet.  I cut out the white sugar, and use a combination of dark and light brown sugar.  I also use 2 Tbsp flour to thicken it a little more.  Love the advice to cook 10 min/400, 20 min/350, 20 min/325 - the crust doesn't darken too much.

text:
I was so excited to find this recipe!  I stopped buying corn syrup years ago, but I didn't want to give up pecan pie at the holidays.  I made several pies with maple syrup, and they tasted delicious but the filling was always too runny, seeping under the crust and making a terrible (though yummy) mess.  I found the texture and flavor of this syrup-less pie to be perfect.  Everyone loved it, and no one would have guessed it was made without corn syrup.  It also keeps very well in the fridge, if there's any left.

text:
I used a pilsbury refrigerated store bought crust & it was awful.  However, from what I could tell, this filling was really good.  I followed the instructions but I think the cooking time was too long - mine got really brown on top.  Next time I'll keep my eye on it & maybe take it out a little earlier or cover the whole pie with foil if it starts to get too brown (I always put a crust protector on).  I put one row of whole pecans on top around the crust just so you could tell what kind of pie it was & it looked OK.  I will definitely try this again with homemade crust & watch the cooking time more closely.

text:
Wonderful, nutty pecan pie! I followed the suggestion of cooking at 350 for 15 minutes and 300 for 10 minutes.  The crust was perfectly golden and crispy.  I also followed the suggestion of toasting the chopped pecans for about 8-10 minutes at 300 beforehand.  This really gave the pie a wonderful flavor.  I love the fact that it doesn't require corn syrup.

text:
First time making a pecan pie, turned out delish!! I bought the graham cracker crust with the '2 extra servings' so I'll get a smaller pie crust next time and less cooking time was needed, I felt mine was a little done. Also, roasting the pecans that go in the filling was a great tip from another reviewer and made the inside have such a hearty nutty flavor. I did the first bake on a higher heat and then after that I put the pecans on top then cooked   the rest of the time. I'll never even try the Karo pecan pie recipe, this is the best!!

Anyways, the pies came out fine.

Wow, gotta say that this made for one amazing pecan pie! Still, amazing pie; This thing didn't last more than a day on thanksgiving when there was a choice of three other pies to be had!

text:
Signing in as another who has previously disliked pecan pie due to the sticky, syrupy, sweetness of it. We can all live without high fructose corn syrup. 

I doubled the recipe and used a double crust, which was absolutely perfect. No need to be nervous, every drop of the mix fit the crust. 

The pie was baked at 350° for 15 minutes, then I reduced the heat to 300° and baked for an additional 55 minutes. During the last 15 minutes, the edges were covered with a pie crust protector. I even allowed an extra ten minutes just in case, without burning it. 

For those of us who are busy or otherwise not inclined to make our own pie crust, Mrs. Smith is your friend. 

It cooks beautifully, but I was a bit dismayed at the texture. My two cents. The middle still seemed loose to me, and was more like scooping a pile than serving a slice. Perhaps increasing the flour, reducing the sugar, adding a little more pecan next time? It could very well be that I tried to double this recipe. Too many others have had great success, so I'm willing to try again.  

Otherwise, the taste is wonderful! Served with ice cream, it was delicious.

This was the best pecan pie I have ever eaten. I made it for my father-in-law who is a pecan pie lover and he thought it was amazing. I changed the cooking times a little I baked 10min at 400. 20 min at 350 and 15min ant 325. I also chopped up 1/2 of pecans, mixed 1/4 of a cup of melted butter, 2 tbls  brown sugar and a dash of vanilla and mixed it all up. I then added it to the top of the pecan pie after I baked it for 10 min at 400. Again Thank you Elaine for the best pecan pie ever.

text:
Simple to make, BUT...this calls for a DEEP DISH pie crust! I bought the regular size and the filling was almost spilling over. It's in the oven now so don't know if it will "cook down" as time goes by.  Ok, this is the next day, after I took the pie to my gathering. Very disappointing! The top of the pie was a pale brown, there were no pecans on top (I guess I should have "dotted them on" as a last touch) and the pie was DRY with little moisture. I attribute this to the lack of corn syrup. The flavor of the pie was good, however. Especially with a dollop of whipped cream!  I guess I'm looking for a recipe that will give me the rich, dark moist texture of a traditional pecan pie without corn syrup.

country:
None
text:
This pie is simple to make and delicious!  It doesn't quite have the stickiness of a karo syrup pecan pie, but it has all of the flavor.  I read the reviews before making and found these comments to be helpful: if using a 9" deep dish pie crust, you have to make an additional half of the filling to fill the crust; bake at 350 for 15 min, then reduce to 300, bake for 50-55 min.  Also, if you want to add an extra dimension to the flavor of the pie, drizzle caramel sauce over the top of the pie when it comes out of the oven or add a heaping tablespoon into the filling.

This was well loved at Thanksgiving. I always make the pecan pie at Thanksgiving, had lost my original recipe I used years ago that used all maple syrup. Never have been a fan of the Karo recipes. It looked a little different (color-wise) coming out of the oven, but the proof is in the taste. Better than the overly sweet syrup kind.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent!  This was my first attempt at a pecan pie and it turned out great.  I searched for a recipe that specifically did NOT use corn syrup.  I would recommend using the "Butter Flaky Pie Crust" recipe on this site for the crust.  Making your own crust isn't as hard as it may seem and it is so worth it, in my opinion.  I also followed someone's advice and baked this at 350 for the first 15 minutes then lowered the temp to 300 for 50 minutes.  I used pecan halves instead of chopped pecans.  One other tip:  when you pour the filling into the crust, it will rise when baking.  I was a little worried at first because I had quite a gap between the unbaked filling and the edge of the pie plate.  It rose during baking though and came out great!

Made this recipe last year and it was a hit! So decided to try again this year!   Only made a few changes: used 2 cups chopped pecans instead of 1. Also, when I made it last year, there was a thick crust on top and the pecans didnt float up. Still tasted great but wasnt as aesthetically pleasing as I would have liked. So this year, I took the nuts and mixed them with a large spoonful of the filling then spooned them over the filling once it was already in the pie shell.   Lastly, followed the suggestion of cooking pie at 350º for 10 minutes, then reducing heat to 300º and allowed to cook for an additional 55 minutes.   Love love love!!
Review:
Rating:
4

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! This was my first ever pecan pie and I cannot believe how great it turned out! I made it for my boyfriend's dad's birthday and he is a pecan pie coniseure. He loved it! I cooked it at 350 for 15 minutes and then 300 degrees for 50 minutes as suggested by some but when I checked it after 60 minutes the middle was still runny so I turned the oven back up to 350. Well that caused it to finish cooking in 20 minutes (I didn't expect it to cook that fast). I actually thought I totally over-cooked it but...it was awesome! That said, I think the temperature depends on your oven and next time I'll cook the pie at a higher temp and check more often. Also, I used "Ruth's Grandma's Pie Crust" and it was the best crust I've ever made.

text:
Yum!!! I've made this many many times, with no changes. However, in an attempt to get healthy, I made some major adjustments last night and it still turned out great! To fill a deep dish pie pan, I used 3/4 Spenda Brown Sugar Mix, 1/2 Cup Splenda, 3/ cup canola oil instead of butter, and 6 egg whites. Still turned out great!! Try this if your looking to stay a bit on the healthy side.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this pecan pie and so does my whole family. I made it for Christmas this year and everyone said it was the best pecan pie they've had. I used a graham cracker crust but the only thing I changed from the recipe is that I added 1/2 cup more pecans and I used the lower baking temp (15 min @ 350, 50-55 min @ 300). It tastes better once it's cooled and allowed to set overnight in the fridge, otherwise it's kind of crumbly when it first comes out of the oven. Tastes great with vanilla bean ice cream.

text:
Great! Added extra nuts, one layer of wholes on the bottom, the mixture, than a topping of arranged whole pecans. Love it very nutty, not all goo like store bought pie. Great for diabetics (splenda makes a brown sugar). The splenda package says to use half the amount of sugar the recipe calls for, don't worry the pie still turns out wonderful. If you make this in a deep pan you need to add extra goo and it seems to take forever to cook, so it works out great in those little foil ones.

text:
I made some modifications and turn out great! I added and extra egg, let the sugars out and substituted with a can of fat free condensated milk, used almost 3 cups of chop pecans and half cup of semisweet choc.chips, 1 tbsp of vanilla and the rest as the original recipe says. I made myself a graham cookie crust instead of the tasteless lardy crusts!! for the baking time i did what the other reviews says at 350 for 12 min and then lowered to 300 for almost 50 min....try it! you won´t be dissapointed! the extra egg and the condensated milk really makes  a huuuge difference!

text:
This pie was exceptional! I made it for Thanksgiving (my first attempt at pecan pie) and it was a hit! My tweaks: I added 1/4 cup of mini chocolate chips, and I used about 2 cups of pecans - which I toasted in a skillet first and right before they were about to get too dark I added a Tb or two of butter (I heard it gets absorbed in as the nut oils get released). I really think that made a positive impact on the pie!

text:
Actually-- 3-1/2 stars. I don't eat pecan pie, but it's my husband's favorite. He said that the crusty top created by the filling was weird, and it was a bit too gooey at the bottom, but the pie tasted pretty good. I was happy to find a syrup-less recipe, so I'll probably try again with a few changes-- lightly mix the ingredients (a couple reviews said too much mixing leaves the filling too fluffy), double the pecans (half for the filling, half on top), and toast the pecans first.

text:
This was an excellent pecan pie, but will not live up to your standards if you want the classic.  It did not have the gooey texture that a classic pecan pie has - it was much more crumbly, but not so crumbly that it didn't stay together well.  I personally loved it, and will make it from here on out on Thanksgiving - the deletion of corn syrup makes the trade off on texture MORE than worth it!

text:
Awesome recipe.  Absolutely delicious and no corn syrup for anyone trying to make a ... ummm ... healthier pie.  :)  Unlike others, I found my pie to be a bit overdone after 10 min @ 400 and 30 min @ 350.  Pie is done when internal temp reaches 200 degrees and mine reached 220 degrees after that time.  Will bake for shorter time next time.

text:
My entire family agreed that the taste of this pie was really good, but it was definitely not a pretty pie.  I don't know if it's the "foaming" of the eggs that does it or what, but the entire top of the pie has a crusty, crumbly layer over it.  So much so that you can't even identify that it is a pecan pie.  So if you don't have corn syrup and it doesn't matter what the pie looks like, this is a good one for taste, but it you want a good looking pecan pie, I would recommend a different recipe.

Never made a pie before, this was my first. My dad who is picky and doesn't even like pecan pie said it was awesome, mom loved it and it passed my fiance's inspection (he's a Georgia boy so that says a lot!)  I threw the pecans in food processor to grind up really good, it gave the pie a nice crumbly texture. Will definately make this again! 5 stars all the way!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I found my pie cooked very quickly, so beware and check often. This caused the top to over-brown and crack on top.  It was messy to cut.  I used a 9in deep dish crust and it was not enough to fill it properly...thankfully this was just a test run.  The pie does not have the same texture as a regular pecan pie, it loses some of the shiny gelatin consistency, but the flavor is that of a regular pecan pie.  I will stick to corn syrup recipes and keep this for back-up when I'm out of corn syrup. I give it 4 stars ONLY because it is a working emergency substitute for corn syrup.

I will say that make sure that you beat the eggs until foamy also make sure the butter is competely melted. I see some people said it did not turn out well. text:
I have never ate pecan pie, so I thought I would try to make one and give it a go.  This pie was very tasty and pretty easy to make.  I didn't make any changes except adding a little more white sugar(I like a sweet pie).  I was a little concerned that it would be mushy because when I took it out of the oven it looked like it wasn't cooked after baking it for 40 minutes.  But I let it sit on the counter for a few minutes and thickened up.  I used a whole wheat buttery crust I made myself and it turned out just great.  Will be making again.

text:
Would give 4.5 stars if possible. I was concerned about making this pie since it wasn't going to be as sweet as a pie made with Karo syrup.  I have a huge sweet tooth.  But, I liked the idea of trying something different and the recipe seemed very easy - and it was.  I wished I had seen the reviews to increase the amount of filling.  It was more shallow than say the pumpkin pies I made but it was adequate.  The taste was suprisingly great and plenty sweet.  I used the store bought roll out crust and added pecans on top for looks.  Next time I think I will add the cinnamon as another reviewer suggested...and increase the amount of filling.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2854401.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe.  Those that say the taste and texture were not good should try it again.  

I followed the recipe with the following additions - the butter and eggs were room temp, added the butter to the mixed eggs while it was still warm/hot, I added a dash of salt and some cinnamon (maybe 1/2 tsp).  350 for 15 minutes and then 300 for 50 minutes.  I made one with splenda and one with the regular sugar both brown and white.  I pulled them out of the oven right before we sat down to eat dinner to let them set and cool, cut into one after dinner to check to see if they were ready and they were.  They were both EXCELLENT.  Yum, yum, yum!

My husband, who is not much of a pecan pie fan, loved it and ate 2 slices and said it was the best pecan pie he's ever had.  He likes that it's not as sweet and sticky as the kind made with corn syrup and so do I.
