text:
This is an excellent pecan pie. I always love easy delicious recipes and am so happy that I have found another one here. I used this recipe to make two pecan pies this weekend, and my husband and friends all gave great comments on the pie. They cannot believe that the pecan pie can taste so delicious without using corn syrup ingredient. I followed other members' suggestion and baked the pie 10 minutes @ 400 degree and lowered the oven to 350 degree for additional 35 minutes. It came out perfect. You may want to let the pie chill for couple hours before you serve the pie. Thanks to Judi for sharing this great recipe!!!!

text:
this was pretty darn tasty. however, something weird happened.  i followed the recipe to the letter, but the pie ended up with a weird crust on the top, that tasted sort of like a meringue, but was brown. the pecans did not rise, so you couldn't tell it was a pie from the looks of it.  i think it might have been because i beat the eggs until they were frothy?  (as i thought the recipe indicated?)  at any rate, it was very tasty even though it looked like no other pie i'd ever seen. ps. the first night, the pie was a little runny, but after being in the fridge it firmed up nicely. perhaps we should have cooked it longer, or let it cool completely before serving?

None
country:
None
text:
Easy, quick recipe. Now karo syrup is one less thing I have to keep in my small pantry. Also, it can be made with an egg beater and I didn't have to clean the big mixer. I use a Pillsbury pie dough in the dairy aisle that you unroll. It is not a frozen pie crust although that would  probably be fine too. Be sure to keep an eye on it while baking, the crust edges brown so quickly I always cover it with foil.  I like serving it with Redi-Whip or ice cream.

text:
Ugh... Thanksgiving meal is over, and I had too much pecan pie like usual. This pecan pie is different... I did not whip the egg whites, but put the eggs in whole as suggested by one reviewer- my pie turned out with a liquidy center and a top crust, nothing akin to a brownie pie. The taste is fabulous, sooooo good, but the texture leaves alot to be asked for- I don't know if it would have been perfect if I'd done the eggs right. Oh- and maybe just a tad less sweet. I can't believe I'm saying that.

I've made this three times, and each time was a wild success! I am a part-time baker and I sell a lot of cakes and cookies, etc. My husband says that this is THE BEST thing I've ever made, hands down. I one and a halfed the ingredients for the filling, it made a fuller pie that way. I cover the edges of my pie with foil so they don't get burnt. I baked it for 10 minutes at 350, took it out and added more pecans on top, then baked it the rest of the way at 300. One is in the oven right now!

My family loves this pie!  I love that i don't have to keep corn syrup on hand for it.  Definitely will be my go-to recipe for pecan pie.  

I know some people have trouble with it not filling the pie shell - never been a problem for me, but I also don't build up the crust too much.  I also use pie shields (or aluminum foil) to protect the exposed crust and it's always turned out well, not burnt at all.

The taste was exceptional, however the appearance was off-putting. I wish that I had read the comments about the soufflé like appearance of the pie if you did not top it with additional pecans prior to baking before I attempted this recipe as one my contributions to Thanksgiving dinner this year. I will definitely make this again, with a few minor adjustments (Additional pecans in the mix and top with pecan halves prior to baking) as the flavor was spot on, and I absolutely love the fact that this perfect flavor was achieved without using corn syrup! Delicious!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious recipe. I love that it doesn't have the corn syrup. I've gone back to this several holidays now. I always cut the white sugar out, bump up the pecans a bit and add a splash of whiskey or bourbon. The biggest problem is that it doesn't make enough to fill the crust all the way to the top, so I've been trying to make about 50% more filling than what the recipe yields. This year, I did 1.5 cups of pecans, 3/4 c butter and three eggs. It filled the shell, but the extra egg made the filling rise pretty high. Luckily, when it cooled the pecan center came back down to earth and all was deliciously well.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this pecan pie for years. Friends ask for it every Thanksgiving. Add extra pecans and toast the chopped ones going into the mix, then add more untoasted ones 10 minutes into baking time. Do the staggered baking  (10 min/400 degrees, 20 min/350 degrees, 20 min./325 degrees ) . My secret ingredient, which I think is what hooks everyone, is 1/4 cup Maker's Mark in the mix along with a little extra flour to help with the extra liquid.

Display Name:
Wistar

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used 1 C dark brown sugar and cut out the white sugar, also used 1 T of cream instead of milk.  I added the remainder of an 8 oz bag of chopped pecans to the top to fill the crust and dropped in 1/2 C of chocolate chips that I intended to put on the bottom, but forgot to put in first, so I just dabbed them in until they sank below the surface.  

I baked it in a small Miele speed oven on convection bake preheated, then baked at 400 for 10 minutes then down to 325 for 60 minutes.  It is the best pecan pie my husband and I have ever had! Not too gooey or sugary and really nutty. I adore pecans but don't like sugary sweets. This is an elegant version that lets the pecans be the star of the show.

text:
This is a great recipe, I feel like the corn syrup ones are just giant blocks of candy, but this one is amazing. What I usually do is run the pecans through a food processor until they're fairly fine, and also mix in chocolate and a bit of bourbon for the filling. Then for the top of the pie I use whole pecans for the aesthetics.  This is a crowd pleaser every year for Christmas!

text:
This  was a simple and tasty pie.  You really can't see the pecans like "traditional" pecan pies unless after pouring the mix in the pie pan you either 1) reserve some pecans to set on top of the pie, or 2) add additional pecans to resemble what a traditional pie might look like.  I laid out the pecans on 1/2 the pie.   Truthfully it isn't necessary as the pie tastes great on it's own.  Just be prepared to know it looks "different".  I will make it again.

Display Name:
kckins

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Use this recipe every Thanksgiving. I always read the other reviews and make some tweaks. This year I toasted the chopped pecans in the oven for about 5 minutes,  added 1 cup of brown sugar to the melted butter and whisked until smooth. Added in 2 tbs maple syrup,  the vanilla as listed, half & half and then added that to the eggs.  I mixed the toasted pecans, plus an additional 1/2 cup that I didn't toast, into the egg mixture and poured it into a GF graham cracker crust. I omitted the flour  entirely.  I baked at 350 for 10 minutes and then lowered the heat to 300 and baked for another 40 minutes. Came out perfect!

text:
I made this instead of my mom's traditional recipe and loved it. I added more pecans in the mix and when I took it out between oven temps (350 to 300) I arranged more on top for a more traditional look. Also, I decided to add a few tablespoons bourbon to the filling and a splash more vanilla (put in a tablespoon or so of extra flour to offset the extra liquid). I liked that it wasn't overly sticky and sweet like the Karo syrup pies. I always place foil around my pie edges so they don't burn or get too brown too.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4586050.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was AWESOME!  My first time making and eating pecan pie...and I’m a convert. It was easy and my hubby and I both loved it. I used refrigerated Pillsbury crust and I floured both sides of the dough before putting in the pie dish (per Pillsbury’s instructions for pecan pie). Added 1/2 cup chocolate chips too. I followed the suggestions to bake at 350 for 15 min then 300 for 40 more minutes. Had just started to crack in the middle...let it sit overnight in the fridge and it was perfect. I served warmed for 12 min at 300 to melt the chocolate.  Yummmm!  Will definitely make again!

text:
I took the advice to bake it at 300 degrees for 45+ minutes, but I also had the problem with the filling coming away from the shell. Also, I just generally don't like the way the finished product looks. I prefer the clear-glossy look at the end where you can clearly see the pecans, rather than a dull brown coating that could have anything under it. It doens't really "shine" or have as presentable of a look. I live in abroad where I can't get corn syrup, but I remember doing another recipe in the past with a honey and/or molasses combo that came out looking more like the classic pecan pie "look." I also prefer keeping the pecans whole!

text:
It was good but such a different texture from the Karo Syrup ones I'm used to. Perhaps I overcooked it or perhaps it's supposed to be drier and less "creamy" than the KS. Also, when I first cut it, it seemed like it just tasted like a brown sugar pie. But the longer it sat, the better it did taste (started losing the overwhelming brown sugar taste) and closer to a real pecan pie taste about 8-10 hrs. later. I will probably just go with Karo Syrup next time, although the only other time I made that one, it didn't set up for me, which is why I wanted to try this one. Maybe it's time to try again, though.

text:
This is the best Pecan Pie recipe I have found, and I have made several. My husband loves Pecan Pie and is quite the connoisseur of Pecan Pie. I always use the Basic Flakey Pie crust recipe from this site, and Baked 350 for 15 minutes and reduced oven to 300 for 50-55 minutes. 
The Pie is a bit sweet, although that is what classic Pecan pie is. This pie ends up with a beautiful finished slight crust to the top of the pie. I also add a layer of halved Pecans to the top of the pie before baking and you can't go wrong with this recipe.

text:
I love pecan pie. I don't like the idea of using corn syrup. This recipe is great! I used about 2/3 of the sugar called for, which I thought worked well as I don't like my desserts too sweet. I also made a cookie crust because it's very difficult to find ready-made pie crusts in Germany. I followed the recommendation of others and cooked it at 350F for 15 minutes and then 300F for 45 minutes. I thought that worked out well. I also made this in a casserole dish because I was worried that my pie dish (which is an 11-inch) would be too big. Would definitely make this again!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made the recipe as is, but I only slightly beat the eggs and sugar, by no means did I get it foamy. I also didn't measure the vanilla so I may have put more. This pie is perfect if you like a denser pecan pie like I do. I covered the crust and left it covered until 10 minutes left. It was a nice golden color and crispy on the bottom (I use pans with holes in them to help the bottom cook better.) The filling puffed up while baking and I got one crack as it cooled but I don't care. The pie could have been filled a little more, but with how sweet it was, it was fine and it reminded me of my grandmother's thin pies. My husband will be asking for this one again for sure.

text:
I've made this, and really, it's my go-to recipe for nut pies of any kind, as my family avoids corn syrup. (Sub in walnuts or hazelnuts sometime- they're just as good, just different!) The only change I've ever made to it is to add MORE nuts, and to bake a little longer. Much, MUCH tastier than the supposedly "traditional" recipes perpetuated by the corn syrup industry- after all, a LOT of our grand & great-grandmothers DIDN'T use the stuff! ;)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husbands birthday is around Thanksgiving and this brown sugar pecan pie recipe has become his - and our family - favorite. I always make two - one for the hubs and one for everyone else! I use the pastry dough from Trader Joe's and it turns out great. (I also use it for pumpkin pie.) Before placing the pie in the oven I create a "halo" from aluminum foil and place that around the pie pan and loosely over the top of the crust to prevent the crust from getting burnt/dry during pies with a longer baking time, a trick I learned from my mom. We also like this pie reheated with a scoop of vanilla ice cream. Yum!

text:
Changes made:
•Doubled amoubt of pecans
• Added chocolate chips
• Reduced temp to 325 for 50 minutes-turned pies at 25 min for even browning
It came out ok. As others have mentioned the top is very different from a traditional pecan pie recipe. It has a puffy/toasted souffle look (due to the foamy egg I'm gussing) 
Is pretty liquidy until sets at least 12 hours. I think next time I will leave out the white sugar as others mentioned and add a tiny bit more flour. 
It was good according to my boyfriend (I don't like pie so I didn't try it) but he didn't do any backflips over it.

country:
None
text:
Amazing recipe, and I'm more of a berry pie girl. Used fresh organic pecans from my dad's tree. Cracking them ourselves was half the fun, but will probably use store bought in a pinch. I added about 1/3 teaspoon of cinnamon, and it was perfect. I cooked for 30 minutes on 300, then another 15 on 350. Once it starts to crack, you know it's ready. I'll be doubling the recipe next time because I prefer no gap between crust and pie, but the taste is still unreal!!

Despite what other people have experienced, this pie came out aces for me. I used walnuts instead of pecans, and used almost 2 cups of nuts rather than 1 cup, and I could not be happier with the result. To avoid a burned crust, I rolled the edge down a bit, and the filling rose to exactly the height of the edge. Great recipe!!

text:
I've made this recipe twice thus far with positive results.  The first time I made this pie, I followed the recipe to a "T" and, as some suggested, added semi-sweet chocolate morsels.  The pie is amazing with and without the chocolate!!  No one missed the corn syrup at all.  The pie has a good balance of sweetness and nuttiness.  Over the years, pecan pie has not been one of my favorite holiday desserts because most pecan pies I've tried are sweeter than I can handle.  I tried my hand at this pie as it is one of my husband's favorite desserts. He and I both loved it! 

The second time I made this recipe, I followed the advice of reviewer BUSIESTMOMOF2 and used refrigerated pie crust to make 24 mini pies.  The filling fits 24 cupcake sized pies nearly perfectly!  Using her suggestion of baking the pies for 25 min at 350 is spot on.  With the exception of the added work that cutting the pie crust and fitting it into the cupcake pan, I much prefer this method.  The little pies doesn't require a reduction in temperature at different times--just pop them in and let them go!  With the little pies, they're perfectly bite sized--no need for utensils!  This is a keeper for sure!

text:
I loved this recipe. I helped my husband's grandmother make it, because she wasn't feeling well. We made two pies, and while putting them in the oven she asked, "Do they go on the top rack or bottom?" The recipe never mentioned what rack. I put them on the top rack, and the pie crust browned almost too much. If you decide to still cook them on the top rack, maybe cover your crust (crust only!) with aluminum foil for half of the cooking time.

The flavor of the pie is spot on, however I did change a few things.  I added an extra 1/2 cup of pecans on top and a few more in the filling. I've made this pie multiple times and the baking temps listed on the original recipe are way too high, if you bake it according to the recipe it will burn.  I bake it at 400 for 10 minutes then 300 for 40 minutes.

I have made this pie.  First time I took chef's suggestion and added chocolate chips. I prefer it the regular way.  However - because it is a very sweet pie, I decided to substutute whiskey for the milk and really liked the outcome.  It cuts the sweetness just a tad. Bottom line is this is a great pie and very quick and easy to make.  My family likes and requests it now.

text:
This is a fantastic classic recipe to keep in rotation! 
I did make a few adjustments over the past few times I have made it, based on other reviews.
I changed the serving size on the recipe to 10 which increased the volume of the filling. I also decrease temperatures.
I cooked the pie at 375 for 10 mins, took the pie out of the oven and preheated oven to 300, the placed the pie back in the oven for 45 mins. 
I then turned off the oven and cracked open the door a bit. I let the pie sit and completely cool in the oven. 
Perfect pie!

text:
This recipe is a keeper! It turned out picture perfect and it sooo good...no more corn syrup for me!  I cut the brown sugar to 3/4 cup (still plenty sweet), added the hot melted butter to the sugars and whisked well to prevent a grainy texture, then added the eggs but did not try to make them foamy (I had no souffle top) and even let it sit for a few minutes to let the few bubbles settle before adding the other ingredients (added an additional 1/2 tsp vanilla and whisked them in lightly and let the mixture sit and settle a few more minutes before baking).  Also, taking the advice of others, I baked at 350 for 15 minutes then lowering the temp to 300 for the remaining time which ended up only being an additional 40 minutes (per the suggestions, the additional time was to be 50 to 55 minutes but mine was already firm after 35 but let it bake another 5 minutes just in case but next time, I won't; I did mention using less brown sugar so perhaps that's why I needed less time).

text:
Easy and delicious. I wanted to try this version because, as many people have mentioned, there is no corn syrup being used. Mom,  boyfriend,  and I loved it. I changed the temperature as many of the reviews suggested to do so.  Baked it at 300° F for about 60 minutes. Added 2 cups of pecans instead of 1. One thing I did that is not in the instructions is that I roasted the pecans before adding them to the mix,  I feel it gives more of a nuttier taste. Thanks for the recipe,  it's a keeper. I love this site and all the people that share all the awesome recipes/tips.

It's great!  I read a number of reviews first, and tweaked the recipe using the recommendations from others.  Dropping the temperature to 300 degrees (instead of 350) worked perfectly.  40 minutes (IMO) is too long - 30 is the magic number.

I love this Pecan Pie easiest one to make and not  caramelized like the one that you add syrup to.I will be making these again and again .I made 2 of these pies preheated the oven to 350 baked for 10 minutes then lowered the heat   to 300 and baked for another 30 minutes  they were delicious the first one I omitted the white sugar and added 1 cup of dark brown sugar I added 2 tsp of flour and a quarter tsp baking powder I added the 1 cup whole pecans  it was good the 2nd one I omitted the white sugar  added 1 cup dark brown sugar and added the 1 cup whole pecans it turned out perfect  I read some people said that it didn;t  fill the pie up to the top I purchased the no name deep dish pie shells and it filled them up  they are not as deep as some of the other deep dish pie shells

text:
I have made this two Thanksgivings in a row, and this year my 21 year old wants this instead of a Birthday cake.  I do about double the pecans, reduce the temp like AJ and Chef Dawn suggested and that does help.  I'd like to mention that this does foam up (for those who haven't done a lot of pecan pies, like me).  This isn't a bug, it is a feature, so don't sweat the decorative pecans on the top too much, because they'll largely be hidden by the foam. ; )

Following others' suggestions, omitted the white sugar and used a few pecan halves on top for appearance.  I didn't have a crust and wanted to save the calories anyway, so made this in a glass pie plate without crust.  At 350 for 10 min and 325 for 30 min it came out perfect.  Southern hubby who has grown up on pecan pie said to make it this way, without crust, from now on!

text:
I LOVE this pie! And it is oh-so easy! I don't like making changes to recipes but I add about 1/2 a tsp of chuncky salt and the other I made I think is more for appearance. I beat an egg white and about 3 Tbsp of sugar until white and fluffy and then added (folded in ) about 3/4cup whole pecans and arranged them on top so the top ended up looking flaky instead of cakey. But ohhhh man I love this recipe! People would NOT stop raving about this pie. Seriously. Four different people told me it was the best pecan pie they have ever had. So thanks!

userID:
14437430
Display Name:
Amber
isPro:

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really disliked pecan pie before I happened upon this recipe.

Mostly pecan pie brought shivers just thinking about the overly sweet dessert that was usually too high in corn syrup and too low in pecans.

I decided to make it for my other family members who happen to enjoy the rush inducing slice of sugary goodness.

Enter this recipe.  Right off the bat I was happy to see the lack of corn syrup.  It's a super simple, straight-forward recipe that relies heavily on technique.

I've made this pie four times all with varying levels of success.  I have baked it too long at 400 and in a panic reduced it to 300 and baked it low and slow covered with foil. That pie was so delicious, chock full of nuts but a little dry.  Add ice cream.

My second and third attempts I used an off brand brown sugar and followed baking temps and times and covered with pie pans after the temp drop.  This resulted in a custardy creamy layer and nice layer of nuts.

My latest attempt I followed all directions precisely omitting the foil and pie pan cover which when taken out had the deceptive crystallized goodness that is the top crust only to yield soup when cut.  We baked it longer.  10 more minutes...until I felt like I couldn't risk the quality of the nuts.  It firmed a bit but still looked quite runny.

However, after letting it sit overnight it firmed up a bit more and is now only slightly caramely, lending nice moisture and texture.  This is my favorite so far.
Review:

5

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5916286.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First, this is not your regular pecan pie but that's what makes it good. I'm not a huge fan of pecan pie but my husband is. He absolutely loved it!  
Second, my suggestion to those trying the recipe for the first time:  bake at 350 degrees for 10 minutes and then 300 degrees for 55-60 minutes. This pie needs to set after baking,  so I suggest making it the night before and refrigerate overnight.  It's better the next day. 
It doesn't look like your traditional pecan pie but then again, it's not!  
I did use 1 1/2 cups of pecan pieces and I added 2 Tblspn of pancake syrup, for flavor.  
I would,  and will,  make this recipe again!  Thank you for sharing it with us!

text:
The one cup chopped pecans are good within the pie filling, but they get mushy. Add another cup pecans to the top of the pie for aesthetics and crunch, as these will toast nicely in the oven:). Also, you can use 3/4 cup of brown sugar and a little less than 1/4 cup of the white sugar and it will still taste great, just less sweet. Happy eating :D.

text:
This pie is awesome! I followed the revisions that were suggested in the reviews. The butter wasn't too hot, I baked for 10 minutes at 350 degrees, took it out of the oven and added pecan halves to the top and then baked for 50 minutes at 300 degrees. I also made sure I used a 9 inch pie pan that wasn't too deep. I did forget to add the tablespoon of flour but the texture of the pie was great. This is a great recipe that I will use again.

This pie is out of this world.  I had never made pecan pie before as I was always turned off by the corn syrup. I used the recipe for Butter Flaky Pie Crust from this site and followed the recipe as indicated in the video. Since I was making mini pies, I thought I'd have to cook them less, but 10 minutes @ 400, and 20 minutes at 350 seemed pretty perfect. I will be enjoying this recipe and sharing it with others!!! text:
Okay, so like many others I was skeptical of this recipe.  I made it anyway and pulled it out of the oven.  We all looked at it and let it sit over night.  Still it didn't look like a pecan pie so nobody tried it.  Then I finally dug in well after dinner!  OH MY WOW!  This is the best pecan pie ever!!!  Seriously!  Everyone loved it after I told them how good it was.  I was one who mixed everything with a mixer and I got a frothy looking top but honestly it tastes like nutty caramel.  I think it could be avoided by not using a mixer at all.  IDK.  This is just so gosh darn good.  I can't even explain it because it's not sickeningly sweet, but it's still a pecan pie!  You've got to try it at least once before shying away from this recipe.

text:
This pie turned out incredible. I tried a different pecan pie the other day, and it was just okay, but this one is going in my recipe box. I followed the suggestion of another reviewer, and cooked the pie at 350 for about 10 minutes, then cooked it at 300 for 45 minutes. I covered the pie edges with tin-foil, and took it off the last 15 minutes of bake time. It came out perfect. The top of the pie had a delicious caramelized texture. My husband even said it was better than his mom's who bakes pecan pies all the time.  I used a frozen pie shell, just the cheap one at wal-mart. This pie was gone in minutes after it was cooled. Best pie ever!!!!

text:
I followed some of the suggestions like first 10 min at 350 then 45 at 300 and it was done, chilled it on the counter 30 mins and in the fridge 30 mins just to make sure it was set. This was my first attempt at a pecan pie so I was playing the guessing game while worrying it would fall apart after trying to slice it so soon after it was done. I also added 1/2 cup extra pecans and reduced the sugar by some. I also reduced the butter by 1 1/2 tbs. This pie was not overly sweet, just right. Will try all brown sugar next time. Got rave reviews even from my ridiculously picky 4 yr old (seriously don't know how he survives sometimes). Will make this again just not too soon, this pie could be trouble cause of how delicious and simple it is to make.

text:
I usually find pecan pie too sweet.  But I had a lot of pecans and wanted to make a pie.  When I saw this recipe, without syrup, I decided to try it.  This pie is the BEST pie I have ever had; I am usually a chocolate or cream kind of person.
I did add 1/2 more cup of pecans and put half pieces on the top so it would look pretty. also I did not have milk, so I used half & half.  I did not have light brown sugar, so I used 3/4 cup dark brown and 1/2 cup white sugar. I had to shell more pecans in the middle of making the pie, so everything sat for a while, too.  I followed the recipe for the temps.  But covered the crust with foil b/c it seemed to be getting brown very soon.  I am not sure why, but the top formed a crust (beautiful, but hard to cut). 
I could not resist this pie and told my husband I would only make this pie to share b/c I do not want to get into the habit of eating a whole pie between just us. : ) 
I am still craving it 2 weeks later. The filling was rich but not as sweet as the syrup pecan pies.  This was truly a gourmet pie. Others who tasted it said it was the best pecan pie they ever had, too.  Will be making again to "share."

text:
This is a 5-star pie in terms of taste!  As others have said, it is not overwhelmingly sweet and I would attribute that to the lack of Karo.  In terms of baking times, I think others are correct.  I started at 350 for 10 minutes, then turned down to 300 for another 40-45 minutes and that was perfect.  Even with the lower temp I still had to use a crust shield to not end up with over-brown edges on the crust.  When I adjusted the temp I followed the suggestion to place pecan halves on the top of the pie in concentric circles.  Very good advice as it really added to the presentation.  This recipe is definitely one I'll go back to - everyone loved it!

This pecan pie tasted really good once it came out and cooled, but it didn't solidify at ALL even after an hour. And after it hardened, it was like a rock :/ I think it calls for too much sugar. Again, tastes great, but next time I make it i will make some adjustments. Go lower on the sugar, and increase the baking time. Some other reviewers suggested putting it on the tray of the oven that gets less heat, I would too, the top browns very fast.

text:
This pie is absolutely fantastic! I made it for Thanksgiving and thought that I would give it a shot due to the great reviews, even though I have a pecan pie recipe that we all love. I am now a convert; this pie is delicious. It isn't dry, which was my fear since pecan pies with Karo are always plenty gooey. No worries! This pie isn't the exact same consistency, it's just a superior product, in my opinion. As far as I'm concerned, I can throw out my old recipe and use this one from now on! The only change I made was that I didn't use chopped pecans, choosing instead to use whole. Thanks for sharing such a great recipe!

text:
Made exactly as written.  The flavor was good, but it wasn't the consistency that I love when eating a pecan pie made with good ol' corn syrup.  This had almost a praline like top.  I baked it at 350 for 40 minutes.  The crust was golden, but the filling seemed to overdone/dry.  Don't get me wrong--still completely edible, just not the ooey-gooey goodness I like in a pecan pie.  If I make it again, I will either lower the final baking temperature or shorten the baking time.  Definitely needs to be eaten warm.

text:
Agree with other reviewers, not overly sweet like the corn syrup version.  I used a homemade 9-inch pie crust and I didn't think there was quite enough filling.  I would increase the recipe by 1/2 (use the "change servings" button and increase servings from 8 to 12) and it would be perfect. Pecan pie always gets too browned in my oven so I bake for 30 minutes and loosely cover the entire pie with foil for the remaining baking time. My total baking time was about 55 minutes. Really good.

text:
This tasted so much more like real food than those corn syrup recipes. I was concerned that real sugar would give this a grainy texture but it was super smooth. I added about 1/8 tsp salt to help bring out the flavors. As others recommended, after pouring the mix into the crust I put some pecans on top. Glad I did as they were the only ones visible once it was baked.

text:
Best Pecan Pie Ever! My whole family liked it better than any others was worried because of some other reviews. I followed the advice of "Chef Dawn" and baked 350 for 15 minutes and then 300 for 50 minutes. I used chopped pecans and overfilled my cup a little. I let my eggs and melted butter come to room temp. When I did my crust I didn't cut any off. I used the 2 finger in a v and one pushing in the middle. I covered with a silicone pie crust cover and my crust was perfect! I also let it sit and cool down before I cut it. It was perfect. Not overly sweet and the pecans were so crunchy. Only way I will fix pecan pie from now on!

text:
This recipe worked great for me! I've never baked any kind of pie before (though I do bake a lot), but I know this turned out well because pecan pie is my boyfriend's favorite and he loved it! I didn't want to make a whole pie so I took a muffin tin and made 12 muffin size tarts. Shaped the pie dough to each tin and baked at 350 for 20 mins. I also added a 1/2 cup of chocolate chips and took the advice of another to let the eggs come to room temperature and make sure not to heat the butter too hot. These were delicious and super easy to make.

text:
I really love the buttery flavor.  I can actually eat it because it isn't too sweet.  I make it all the time and it is a crowd pleaser.  Not so much a fan of the way it crusts st top.  Even if I top the pie with pecans instead of mixing them in, it still crusts up like that.  Not sure if it's a technical issue or if it's related to the ingredients.
**update**
I find that beating the eggs less reduces the crunchy top myself and other reviewers complain about.  Scramble the eggs lightly instead of beating them until foamy.  Also, reduce oven temp to 350 for ten mins and 300 for 40 mins.  I wait to put whole or halved pecans on top of pie until after the first ten mins so that the nuts stay on top.   These adjustments make a tremendous difference!  I also double the recipe and bake 4" pies, yielding 8 mini pies.  
For those who think this pie is too sweet:
There is a similar recipe in current Southern Living Cakes and Pies magazine (displayed until Aug 15).  It is called Utterly Deadly Southern Pecan Pie.  It has bourbon, lower sugar amounts, and different baking instructions.

text:
My family and I enjoyed this pie.  It was the first time I made it and I was at my brother's house.  Not being familiar with the oven, I thought I had reduced the temperature as directed but I was wrong.  It baked at 400 degrees for about an extra 10-15 minutes.  I successfully reduced the temperature to 325 and baked it for about 10 minutes.  The edge of the crust was burned so I cut it off.  The benefit to this mistake is that the pecans were wonderfully crunchy and carmelized on top.  Next time, I'll probably do the same but cover the crust with foil.   It was a "Happy little accident."
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2012-12-07T11:15:57.523

text:
This pie is excellent!!! I didn't even like pecan pie before I made this one! My hubby would be the one to order a slice for desert on occasion and I would sometimes have a taste but I always thought they were too sweet and just didn't taste that great. This is the first pecan pie I've made and it will be the only recipe I ever use. It is very easy to make, has great flavor and it isn't sickly sweet. I used regular brown sugar, whole ground vanilla beans instead of extract (awesome fruity flavor if you haven't used this before) and used pecan halves rather than chopped. Delicious by the slice and cut into bite size for a desert tray :)

None
country:
None
text:
OMG is this good!  Because I had a deep dish pie shell I increased everything by 1/3.  I was a little short on pecans so substituted 1/3 cup walnuts that I mixed with the liquid mixture.  After pouring this into pie plate I then placed pecans on top.  This way they did not "sink" into the mixture as one reviewer mentioned as a problem.  I did cut out the white sugar because I don't like it overly sweet.  Although I increased all other ingredients by 1/3 I kept the butter (1/2 cup) the same.  Decided to make this last minute on Thanksgiving and it was quick, easy and yummy.  Restaurant quality for sure!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a rockin' pecan pie recipe! Little different than the others, and that makes it just that much better, IMHO.


The standard recipe is very good with no need for alteration. Next time, I will probably add another 1/3 cup of chopped pecans because I think it can take it - and I like a little more nuts and a little less filling in my pie. Having said that, I still recommend that you try this recipe without alterations first, as it might be the perfect pie for you.


I doubled the batch and baked two pies at the same time on the wire rack with no baking sheet. About half way through baking, I rotated the pies 180 degrees. I let them cook a few extra minutes since there were two pies baking.


For crusts, I used the Pillsbury Pet Ritz frozen variety, thawed before filling, of course.


Hope this helps!

I know there have been some complaints about the foamy top, but this is all you have to do to counter that.  Oh, I did also have to make 1 1/2 recipes to fill my pie crust and then increase cooking time to compensate, but this is common for me.  I will definitely make this recipe again and again!

text:
This was my first attempt at a pecan pie and it turned out great! I baked it for 35 minutes, which turned the top very brown and crispy.  I think next time I will only do 30 minutes.  The taste and texture (aside from the crispy top) were wonderful.  Everyone commented how it's not as sickeningly rich as most pecan pies are.  That may be because there is no corn syrup in this recipe.  We all preferred this version.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Thank you for the amazing pecan pie.  My southern wife complimented me, saying it was pretty good, to be made by a northern boy.  I followed the baking instructions exactly, but covered the edge of the crust with foil and then removed it during the last 15 minutes of baking. 

     Also, followed the advice of others to mix the sugars with the butter first, than vanilla, milk, (room temp. whisked)eggs, flour, and pecans.  Made for a nice smooth mix.  Don't forget to smatter the top with pecan halves. 
     
     For the crust I used 1/2 cup of virgin coconut oil, 1/2 tsp of salt, 1 1/3 cups of flour, and 3 tblsp of cold water.  Made for a tender flakey crust packed full of good fat that complimented the filling well.

text:
After reading other reviews, I was concerned about not filling up a deep dish crust.  I doubled the recipe, but increased pecans to 3 cups total.  As another reviewer suggested, I toasted the pecans for 6 minutes before adding them and used the brown sugar/splenda variation of another reviewer.  Had plenty of filling to fill up 2 deep dish crusts.  Absolutely yummy!  Mu husband loved it!  The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is that there is a lot of fat - 1 stick of butter per pie.  So I definitely would not double the filling to make 1 pie - too much fat.

text:
I want to preface my comment by saying that I have always hated pecan pie and that I, to this day, am not  a pecan pie fan. With that said, even I have to admit that this is, by far, the best pecan pie I have ever tasted! I tried a bite just to make sure that it tasted good enough to serve to others (my husband begged me to make him a pecan pie for Thanksgiving -- I know, I'm a little late with my review) and the pie was great. I still don't like the pecans themselves, but the rest of the pie was truly savory. The pecan pie fans raved about it so much that it convinced non-pecan pie fans to try it and they raved about it, too! I will be making this every Thanksgiving for my husband and will gain a few fans of my baking in the process. Thanks for a great recipe!

I set out to make a sweet potato/pecan pie for my Thanksgiving dessert, only to realize that my husband hates sweet potato! So at the last minute, I whipped up this pecan pie. It was easy and completely delicious! More caramel-y than the recipes that use corn syrup, which I liked very much. My guests (and husband) also loved it, and it was the first 'leftover' I reached for as I was cleaning up this morning! I only wish that there had been more of the pie filling, because there wasn't quite enough to fill the pie crust. I will definitely make this again.

region:

country:

text:
I was really skeptical that I could make a good pecan pie because I have always thought they were hard. I was so wrong! This pie was SO delicious and EASY! I actually doubled the recipe because when I poured it into the pie crust it didn't look very full so I just made a second batch, yes it was that easy! I also used pecan halves and put them on the top instead of mixing them in to the filling. I had to cook it a lot longer than it specified. I think I cooked it for over an hour. I turned it down to 300 after about 30 minutes at 350. I thought it wasn't going to get firm but it eventually did. Needless to say, this will be a desert I cook often! So easy and very delicious!

country:

text:
UH. MAY. ZING. Loved how it wasn't overwhelmingly sweet!  I did use 1 tbsp of Splenda  in the place of the white sugar to cut some of the calories. Also I made sure to temper my eggs when adding the hot butter, and strained the egg-butter mixture to prevent cooked egg pieces in the pie.  Took the advice of some of the reviews and reduced the temp gradually - ended up with a nice, crispness on the top of the filling. Tried this for Thanksgiving this year - was a big hit with my family, so much that they requested I bake another one!

text:
I made this with a canola oil/flour crust off this site, and it was alright, but not the best. My fiance loves pecan pie and won't eat it. He said it reminded him of the kind of pie they serve at a place like Denny's. His complaint was that it didn't have enough pecans, even though I did the 1 cup chopped plus pecans on top. If you like a lot of pecans in your pie, I suggest adding an extra 1/4 cup or more to mixture. I baked mine at 350 for 15 minutes and 300 for 55 minutes, as a previous reviewer suggested. It did not burn that way, which was a nice change from my mom's pie, but it was a little too soft on the bottom for my liking that way.

country:
None
text:
This recipe was fantastic, and so easy to make! 

Instead of light brown sugar, I used dark brown sugar, and instead of vanilla extract, I just added some vanilla sugar. I baked the pie on a low level in 175c for 10 minutes, and then for additional 40 minutes at 150c. 

Recipe for crust:
3,5 dl flour
125 g cold butter
2 tbsp sugar
1/4 tsp salt
1,5 tbsp cold water

Mix the butter and the flour by hand, add sugar and salt, and enough water to form a ball.

text:
Delicious!!!  I haven't made pecan pie in years and this recipe is definitely a keeper.  I really don't know what the reviews that discuss the top not looking like a "traditional pie" are talking about.  Pecans float to the top, that is why you are supposed to mix them into the batter.  They will surface, but the mixture on them also gives them that carmelized flavor.   Very yummy.  You can rearrange them after they float to the top for presentation or you can not mix them in and arrange them on top after you fill your pie crust.  Either way, this pie is sooooooo good.

text:
I don't care what anybody else says this pie is AMAZING!! This was my first time making pecan pie for our big family Thanksgiving and I was hesitant because it did not have corn syrup and it was the most asked for dessert but after reading the reviews and seeing the ratings I decided to try it. It was a major hit and out of the 6 pies we had it was the first to go! It didn't have that sickening syrupy sweetness but was still sweet enough for my hubby who has a major sweet tooth, it's the best one he's ever had he said. I doubled the recipe to fill a 9-inch deep dish pie crust and followed the suggestions of others and lowed to the temperature to 350 for 15 minutes and then 300 for 50-55 minutes. I will definitely be making this for Thanksgivings to come!

3
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Since I'm diabetic, I figured if I want to enjoy my favorite desserts, I need to learn to make them myself since a lot of the store sugar-free or no sugar added don't always taste great. I took a risk this year on Thanksgiving and attempted my first pie from scratch ever with this recipe. I substituted the sugars with the Splenda blends and it turned out very good but not like your traditional pecan pie...drier? (I'm sure it has something to do with the way Splenda doesn't carmelize exactly like regular sugar? I dunno). It turned out more like pralines which I absolutely love. I ended up converting a lot of my family members who usually do not like pecan pie and also impressed a few of my family members who grew up in the south. I would definitely use this recipe again..maybe adjust it a little to accomodate to my needs :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm giving this a 4 star based solely on taste (which is really the most important thing!). I received nothing but good reviews from my family when I made this yesterday. However, it does not look anything like your typical pecan pie. I even arranged halved pecans on top in a cute little arrangement, but during cooking they all sank down into the pie which left the top with just a plain looking brown crust.  One piece of advice that I followed from other reviewers is that if you have a deep dish pie crust, the filling will not fill the crust adequately. I doubled the recipe but was left with a bit of filling left over. Next time I wouldn't quite double it, but it definitely needs more than what is listed if you have a deep dish. I also lowered the bake temp and increased time. Would definitely make again.

text:
This was not the prettiest pie I have ever seen, but it was one of the most delicious.  My husband and I decided that the pie's appearance must be a defense mechanism to dissuade predators off from eating it.  I found that the amount of filling was a little scant and the next time I make it I will either use an 8 inch shell or increase the recipe by 50%.  The directions are confusing since they indicate that the oven should be preheated to 350 but then the cooking directions indicate that the pie should be started at 400.  I ended up overcooking it a little.  However, the pie is so good, that even with clear baking instructions, it turned out terrific.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This pie is amazing! I made it for Thanksgiving this year and read the reviews first. I actually wound up doubling the recipe and I baked it in a 9.5" deep pie dish. I ran out of brown sugar so I just added a little more white sugar to make up the difference. I followed other reviews and baked the first 15 mins at 350 and then reduced it to 300. After 50 mins I thought it was still rather runny inside even though there was a light colored crust on top. So I took a knife and broke down the crust and mixed it back into the batter and baked another 30 mins at least, maybe longer (I just kept checking it).   It turned out great and I can't wait to make it again!

text:
I am floored that I actually pulled this off!  I modified the recipe and used a mini muffin pan, ready made pie crust, and made pecan pie bites.  I increased the pecans by 1/2 a cup but I would use 1 cup the next time.  I also toasted the pecans beforehand and was forced to use pecan pieces because all the stores around were out of chopped. I also cooked it at 400 for about 10 minutes and turned it down to 350 for another 15 minutes.  I will cook it for 5 minutes less next time.  My mom has already eaten 2, so I will need to hide them until guests arrive!  These are delish I will probably make them for the other upcoming holidays!

text:
My first homemade pie and I liked it.  It's not as gooey as the first-ever pecan pie I tasted in my life, I think that's a good thing.  My only modification was I reduced the amount of sugars (3/4 cup packed brown sugar and 1/8 cup white).  It was still too sweet for me and my husband so I'll be using less sugar next time, but it's a hit for my finicky five-year-old and my eat-almost-anything three-year-old. I wonder if the top should really turn out as crunchy as mine did.  Anyway, thanks for sharing this recipe.

text:
Absolutely fantastic pecan pie! Love it! I made it yesterday morning and it is almost gone. I have a small container for a fried as well ( otherwise I think I would eat the whole pie ). My daughter loves it too and I can't wait to make it again. Used just under the 1/4c white sugar but left everything else the same. Cooked 10 mins on 165 ( forced fan oven ) and then reduced cooking time to 30 mins on 140 degrees. Had to cover about 20 mins into the last part of cooking to prevent edges from getting too dark. Still turned out perfect! Will make again and again, smiles!  This is the 2nd time I am rating this recipe again 5 stars. I have made it twice now with macadamia nuts and it is beautiful. A fab recipe for both pecan or macadamia pie. Love them both. I always get asked for the recipe or to bring a pie along to a get together....... YUMMY!!

I toasted my pecans before I mixed them in and I topped the pie with pecan halves arranged in concentric circles.  Will definitely make again.

text:
I have not been a huge pecan pie fan, but my husband is and we both love this pie.  I took this pie for our Thanksgiving dinner and everyone raved about it.  I made several pies at several different times.  The first one I made as listed,but turned down the temp to 300 for the last 10 minutes.  The second one I made with the suggestion of 400 then turning it down for 50 minutes.  When I did that the center of my pie fell after taking it out of the oven.  I didn't take that to our Thanksgiving dinner thinking it was ruined but kept it for ourselves.  It wasn't ruined, it still tasted wonderful, but the presentation wasn't great.  This will be the only pecan pie I make in the future.  I always hated the corn syrup taste.  Thank you for a wonderful pie.

text:
I bake often but have never made pecan pie (because I am not fond of it) but it was requested for Thanksgiving.  Used this recipe and it was a total hit. My oven is convection so followed the directions for 300 degrees after 15 mins at 400. Baked a total of 75 mins and it was a beautiful golden brown, not dark. I used 2 cups of pecans. Drizzled melted caramels (16 Kraft) plus 1 T heavy cream over top for design. Not difficult in the least and a sure thing!!

This Pecan Pie was excellent !  I was hesitant to make it because some reviewers did not like its presentation.  I was very pleased with the looks and the taste.  I made a 10 inch pie so I did make a recipe and a half of the filling.  The only changes I made to the recipe and a half was to only use 1/4 cup of white sugar and 2 cups of chopped pecans. It was really plenty sweet and was enjoyed by all. I will certainly make again.  Thanks for the excellent recipe.

I work at the Firehouse and had to pull duty on Thanksgiving.  My Captain requested Pecan Pie. I have never made pecan pie before, used this recipe for the very first time. Oh My Goodness, it is amazing. These guys are the toughest food critics out there. Firemen regard themselves as lords of the kitchen. They were impressed and stuffed themselves. Use this recipe and follow the suggestion of oven temp variations and you will have a pie to die for. also, I drizzled ever so lightly caramel ice cream topping in a criss-cross pattern on the top. YUM !!! It was amazing, and I have lived in Tennessee where pecan pie is king!

best best ever !

Delicious...a great and nutty pie without all the ooey, gooeyness!
I increased the filling ingredients by 1/2 because I had a deep dish and it helped bring the filling level up more appropriately.  Everyone raved about this pecan pie.  I also decreased the white sugar amount (and will probably leave out next time) by 1/2 and kept the brown sugar the same, and it was really plenty sweet.  With diabetics in attendance, I was happy to offer this as an option to all of the other traditional holiday treats.  Thanks for the great recipe- I will definitely bake this again!!

text:
Thia recipe turns out a wonderful pecan pie that everyone will love.  It is so easy and tastes great. I used 1 1/2 cups of medium pecan pieces and a some more for the top as others suggested and it looked great.  I did not have any light brown sugar in the pantry so I used all organic cane sugar, which is not white, but not quite light brown. It still tasted and looked good. I baked at 400 for 15 minutes and 45 minutes at 350. Thanks for the new and way improved version of pecan pie!

Don't expect this to be like a standard pecan pie. Its not as custard-like or eggy. It forms a very crusty top. I like the idea of not having to use corn syrup, so next time I'll try adding another egg.

text:
This is one of the pies I made for Thanksgiving and it was well received. I was in a bit of a hurry when I made it, so used the beater to mix all and only stirred in the pecans. It had kind of a caramel taste/texture that I really enjoyed. Extra points for not having the leftover corn syrup bottle in the way in the refrigerator!

I did not like this at all.  The filling was not enough, so I doubled the recipe.  I guess I just like the old karo syrup way of making it after all.
